Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last significant rain and snowfall occurred on December 1st and 2nd when most NWAC weather stations recorded 3-5 inches of precipitation and the Mt Hood area received over 10 inches of water. Most of the precipitation fell as rain at mid and lower elevations with higher terrain receiving rain then 1-2 feet of snow. 

, ' ',

That last warm storm in early December helped form a very thick and strong crust layer with initially very good bonding of the new snow to the forming crust. There was little avalanche activity following this storm with colder low density snow allowing for some loose slides on some steep slopes but little slab avalanche activity was noted.  

, ' ',

At mid and lower terrain a still shallow snowcover is limiting the avalanche potential in many to most areas with significant terrain and vegetative anchoring remaining in place.

, ' ',

Over the past week the Pacific Northwest has been in the freezer, under a cold and dry northerly flow aloft. During this dry period there have been periods of strong easterly ridge top winds, mainly last Friday and Saturday, that transported loose surface snow and built some small wind slabs on some lee slopes. There were some triggered shallow wind slab releases noted, mainly near Crystal Mountain on East peak. 

, ' ',

The strong east winds shifted to strong west to northwest winds Sunday, continuing through Monday. This has again redistributed weak loose surface snow back to some easterly facing slopes below higher ridges building additional but isolated wind slab.

, ' ',

The cold dry weather has also been active above and through the surface snow with thick surface hoar growth in many areas as well as producing abundant near surface faceted snow. In addition, the cold temperatures and hence strong temperature gradient in the upper snowpack, have allowed for the initial good bond of new snow to the crust to begin weakening.   

, ' ',

Photos of near surface facets and surface hoar, Monday 12/09 by WSDOT avalanche forecaster John Stimberis at Snoqualmie Pass:

, ' ',

Warmer and drier air moving across the Pacific Northwest Wednesday should allow for some slow settlement of recently formed wind slab in the alpine. Recent strong winds have exposed firm or hard ice crusts and produced a wide variety of snow surfaces at higher elevations.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last significant rain and snowfall occurred on 1 and 2 December when NWAC weather stations near and west of the crest recorded 3-5 inches of precipitation and the Mt Hood area received over 10 inches of water. Most of the precipitation fell as rain at mid and lower elevations with higher terrain receiving rain  and then 1-2 feet of snow.

, ' ',

The storm at the start of December helped form a generally thick, strong crust with generally cohesionless new snow above the crust. There was little avalanche activity following the storm with colder low density snow allowing for some loose slides on some steep slopes but little slab avalanche activity was noted..

, ' ',

Over the past week the Pacific Northwest has been in the freezer under a cold and dry northerly flow aloft. During this dry period there were strong easterly ridge top winds, mainly last Friday and Saturday, that transported loose surface snow and built some small wind slabs on some lee slopes. A shallow wind slab was triggered on East Peak near Crystal Mountain. 

, ' ',

Then the winds shifted to strong west to northwesterly on Sunday and Monday. This redistributed weak loose surface snow back to some easterly facing slopes below higher ridges building additional isolated wind slab.

, ' ',

The cold dry weather has also been active in the surface snow producing thick surface hoar growth in many areas and near surface faceted snow.

, ' ',

So there is quite a mix of snow surfaces out there on Wednesday. This varies from small areas of shallow wind slab and scoured or icy surfaces at higher elevations near ridges to hoar frost, near surface facets or powder on sheltered slopes and at lower elevations.

, ' ',

Also at lower elevations shallow snow cover is still limiting the avalanche potential especially in the Olympics, the south Cascades and along the Cascade east slopes due to terrain and vegetation

, ' ',

Photos of near surface facets and surface hoar, Monday 12/09 by WSDOT avalanche forecaster John Stimberis at Snoqualmie Pass:

, ' ',

A front and upper trough should cross the Northwest on Thursday. This will cause southwest winds and increasing rain or snow with the rain or snow reaching the Olympics Thursday early morning and the Cascades Thursday late morning. This should result in new storm slab on a variety of slope aspects and new wind slab on lee slopes. These new storm and wind slab layers will build on a variety of previous snow surfaces including the scoured or icy surfaces at higher elevations and hoar frost, near surface facets or powder at lower elevations. So I would expect some potential dicey conditions out there by later Thursday.

Hood and east slopes. This storm cycle created a strong and

column8:
>Heading into the Thursday afternoon/night weather system, a variety of snow surfaces are present including isolated areas of shallow wind slab and scoured or icy surfaces at higher elevations near ridges, especially above treeline on Mt. Hood, hoar frost near and below treeline, and near surface facets or powder on sheltered slopes and at lower elevations. Thin sun crusts have also been reported on steeper solar aspects. 

, '\n\n',
column13: >At the lower elevations shallow snow cover is still limiting the avalanche potential, especially in the Olympics, the south Cascades and along the Cascade east slopes due to terrain and vegetation.

column1: The most significant loading from new storm and wind slab will occur late Thursday afternoon through Friday morning at higher elevations. The new storm snow and wind deposited snow is expected to bond poorly to the variety of existing snow surfaces. Natural avalanche activity will likely be limited by the amount of loading on the newly buried weak layers and crusts. In areas that receive more wind transport and loading expect a higher likelihood of natural avalanches. Continued light showers and a warming trend during the day Friday will continue to stress the underlying snow.

The snowpack is expected to be sensitive on Friday, mainly above treeline.  If venturing out into the backcounty on Friday, conservative trip planning and decision making in the field will be essential for safe travel. No reports of the quality or sensitivity of the bonding between new to old snow surfaces were available at the time of this forecast.

This storm cycle created a strong and

On Thursday, several hours of very strong westerly winds hit the Cascade crest, especially as recorded by NWAC weather stations at Washington Pass and the Mission Ridge ski area. This wind transported loose surface snow and likely built pockets of wind slab. There were some ski triggered but relatively shallow slab releases reported in the Mt Baker area both Thursday and Friday.

, ' ',

A weak front has now moved across the region as of Friday and it turned out to be weaker than expected. Only shallow new snow was received over the east slopes, generally few inches or less.
column6: >Any local unstable storm or wind slabs should slowly improve with the expected warming Saturday but still require diligence in assessing the local snowpack conditions as there should be widespread differences in local conditions due to variations in recent storm snow.
column7:
> 

, ' ',

Any shallow storm or wind slab layers that have recently formed overlie weak low density snow, surface hoar or exposed crust layers. While these potential unstable layers might be sensitive in areas they should remain relatively shallow in most areas.

, ' ',

Lower elevations have significantly less snowcover, thus helping limit the avalanche potential.

, ' ',

column1: High pressure should rebuild along the coast Saturday producing warming and generally light crest level winds. This weather should allow for wind or storm slabs to gradually settle in place as the weak underlying snow further consolidates. This should lead to an overall slowly decreasing danger. However, pay close attention to local conditions, especially if the area you are traveling in received more significant new snow. Watch for evidence of wind transported snow or potentially unstable pillows overlying the likely weak snow formed over the past week.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last significant snow fell over the first few days of December along. This storm produced rain to relatively high elevations followed by a significant cooling trend that deposited up to 1 foot or more of low density snow over most east slope sites. Following this storm cycle, a strong and
column2:
> generally thick rain crust formed below the gradually lower density surface snow and also formed a relatively good bond to this crust. With the cooling profile and lack of significant wind, little avalanche activity occurred shortly after the storm.  

, '\n\n',
column3: >Dry and very cold weather followed with periods of both strong easterly ridge top winds a week ago, then strong west to northwesterly winds last Sunday and Monday. This

column6:
> from strong temperature gradients within the upper snowpack.

, ' ',

On Thursday, several hours of very strong westerly winds hit the Cascade crest, especially as recorded by NWAC weather stations at Washington Pass and Mission Ridge ski area. This wind transported loose surface snow and did build pockets of wind slabs in higher lee terrain.

, ' ',

The surface snow conditions have all but changed as of this Saturday as a result of significant warming and a little light rain or heavy dense snow Thursday night and early Friday. Precipitation amounts remained very light along the east slopes but helped to settle and consolidate older low density surface snow. 

, ' ',

Most areas only received about 2-8 cm (1-3 inches) of snow or light rain at mid and lower elevations by early Friday. As a result there have been few reports of activity as of Saturday afternoon. Given a full day of warm temperatures, some previous light rain or heavy wet snow late Thursday, this will likely settle the previous low density snow making triggered releases much more difficult from any remaining shallow wind or storm slab layers.  These potential unstable layers may remain more sensitive on some steep shaded northeast facing terrain at the highest elevations, though remaining relatively shallow in most areas.

, ' ',

column1: A very weak front should move through the high pressure ridge Sunday. Only very light amounts of precipitation are expected overnight Saturday and Sunday at initially high freezing levels but with a cooling trend. This weather should further allow for any unstable layers to bond and settle in place as warm dense surface snow helps to consolidate older weak snow from last week, causing an overall slowly decreasing danger. However, pay close attention to local conditions, especially if the area you are traveling in received more significant new snow. Watch for evidence of any wind transported snow at higher elevations where colder surface snow may be available to transport to lee slopes.

The last major storm was at the start of the month. This storm produced heavy rain followed by Arctic cooling that deposited up 6-12 inches of low density snow east of the crest.

Several hours of west winds and a warming trend hit on Thursday such as was recorded by the NWAC weather station at Washington Pass and Mission Ridge. This would have transported loose surface snow and likely built pockets of shallow wind slab east of the crest. Weak layers would be provided by some of the recently buried hoar frost or near surface faceted snow.

, ' ',

Light amounts of wet snow would have been seen east of the crest later Thursday and early Friday. This may have cause shallow storm conditions but reports are lacking east of the crest.

, ' ',
column6:
>Warmer weather should be continuing to destroy old weak layers and is causing consolidation and stabilizing and a variety of minor wet snow conditions in most areas Saturday and today. Small shallow wet loose avalanches, roller balls, pinwheels and shallow wet snow conditions are reported from many areas.

, '\n\n ',

column1: An upper ridge should amplify over the US west coast on Monday. This should cause mostly dry and even warmer weather on Monday. Plenty of sun should be seen in the central and especially the south Cascades. But the sun is weak at this time of year.

The main effects of this weather should be to cause recent snow to further consolidate and further stabilize. Wet loose avalanches should be the main consideration and this should be mainly but not exclusively on steep solar aspects. Watch for increasing roller balls, pinwheels, wet surface snow deeper than a few inches and natural avalanches.
Isolated pockets of wind slab may also linger at the highest alpine elevations east of the crest where temperatures have been cooler and delayed the stabilizing of these layers.

column1: Mild or warm temperatures should generally persist at Mt Hood Tuesday. Then the south part of a greatly weakening front will begin to reach Mt Hood Tuesday night.

The main effects of this weather Tuesday should be to cause the snow pack to further consolidate and further stabilize. Mostly small wet loose avalanches should still be the main concern Tuesday at Mt Hood and this should be mainly but not exclusively on steep solar aspects. Watch for roller balls, pinwheels, wet surface snow deeper than a few inches and natural avalanches.

column2: >New rain or snow should only reach the Mt Hood area Tuesday night. Overall new snow amounts should be very light at Mt Hood and should not cause an extensive new avalanche danger by Wednesday morning.

Several hours of strong westerly winds and a warming trend hit the north Cascades last Thursday. This built pockets of shallow wind slab that produced some skier triggered releases at the Mt Baker ski area: releases failed on some of the recently buried hoar frost and/or near surface faceted snow.

, ' ',

About 2-9 inches of wet snow was seen late Thursday to Friday morning with the most at Paradise. This produced some more 6-12 inch skier triggered storm slab releases at the Mt Baker ski area on Friday and some shallow storm slab around Mt Hood Meadows.

column1: A weak system will cross the Pacific Northwest Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning and should produce only light amounts of new snow along with a cooling trend.  Little to no precipitation is expected around Mt. Hood through Wednesday morning.  Light showers on Wednesday should increase in intensity in the late afternoon or evening, occasionally becoming moderate for the west slopes of the Cascades before a sharper drying and cooling trend takes hold Wednesday night.

column2: >New shallow wind slab may be found above treeline on elevations on Wednesday, generally on N through SE aspects. Although the recent warming has helped to stabilize the upper snowpack, weak layers may be still be found under Thursday's most recent snow and may be sensitive to the light additional loads received Tuesday night and Wednesday, especially for any areas that receive more snow than forecast.

column1: A cold and dry forecast Thursday with increasing clouds in the afternoon should do little to change the current avalanche danger.  Isolated and lingering wind slab may still be present above treeline, mainly on lee easterly aspects.

A more interesting and dangerous avalanche setup will occur late Thursday night but mainly on Friday as moderate precipitation loading occurs along with rising snow levels and strong winds Friday.  This storm will likely test the strength and bonding of the near surface weak layers as well as introduce new snow instabilities.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Early December storms ranged from rain to high elevations followed by cooling with up to 1 foot of snow. No significant storms have occurred since early December. However, there have been significant variability in temperature regimes ranging from very cold temperatures to recent high freezing levels and warm temperatures early this week.

, ' ',

Very warm temperatures over the weekend through this Tuesday produced some wet snow avalanches on steeper slopes, though none were reported along the east slopes. Initial news from an off-duty patroller at Crystal Mountain Thursday saw evidence of a recent wet loose snow avalanche on a south facing slope that stepped down to the ground Monday.  The slide likely stepped down on a pocket of depth-hoar possibly found near rocks and shallower snow cover. Since a shallower snowpack exists along the east slopes, this type of slide remains possible, though unlikely especially if strong crust layers remain.

, ' ',
column2: >Stevens Pass DOT avalanche professionals reported faceted layers surviving below
column3:
>crust interfaces (including the early Dec crust 30cm down) with easy compression test releases. 

, ' ',

Significant cooling Wednesday and Thursday with some light snow has now formed a new near surface crust in most areas with some shallow trace to few inches of new snow on the surface. 

, ' ',
column4:
>Shallow snow cover is limiting the avalanche danger at lower elevations.

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

column1: The strongest storm in some time should begin to deposit shallow snow Thursday night and increase and become light to moderate through the day Friday along with significant warming and strong crest level winds.
This stormmay test the strength and bonding of the near surface weak layers as well as introduce new storm slab instabilities.

The storm should begin with very cold temperatures Friday morning and this should deposit a layer of low density snow over a firm crust. Temperatures should rise through the afternoon along with increasing precipitation rates. This should build increasingly unstable storm slabs through the day causing an increase in the danger. By midday and through the afternoon there will be an increasing likelihood of triggered or possible natural slides, especially near and above treeline in areas receiving the heaviest precipitation.
The strong west to northwest crest level winds will also build unstable dense wind slab on lee slopes near ridges.
This storm should cause dangerous avalanche conditions near and above treeline where travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended by later Friday.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

UPDATED SATURDAY MORNING FOR FREEZING RAIN SEEN AT MT HOOD MEADOWS - SEE FORECAST BELOW

, ' ',

Warm weather last weak created another strong crust layer in most areas. Light amounts of low density some as well as some surface hoar formation occurred over the past few days. This has set the stage for the strong storm that moved through the region Friday. The latest strong storm began with light snowfall at very cold temperatures early Friday, adding to the weak snow overlying a strong crust. This weak near surface snow has been loaded by moderate to heavy amounts of snow at warming temperatures creating unstable conditions.

, ' ',

Friday morning control routes at Mt Baker Ski area were releasing sensitive ski triggered wind slabs on exposed northerly facing terrain in the Mt Baker area ranging up to 30 cm (1 foot). By mid-morning Friday additional loading had built further very sensitive wind slab layers.

, ' ',

The warming and heavy precipitation rates have tipped the balance in many areas given the weak underlying snow all atop of firm crust layers. 

, ' ',

There has been a variety of snow crystal types reported falling through the day Friday, ranging from sleet, mixed rain and snow, graupel other unknown grains. The Crystal Mountain area reported a new crust layer forming by midday to the top of the ridges as a result of temperatures in the mid 30's and mixed precipitation forms. 

, ' ',

As a result of high variability in temperatures as well as precipitation types
column4: >during Friday's storm, expect an equally wide variety of local snow stability and plan your routes with a high degree of flexibility based on local conditions. Expect to encounter n
column5: >ew wind slab layers as well as storm slabs and persistent slabs, especially in areas receiving the greatest amounts of storm precipitation, such as the volcanic peaks and central WA Cascade Passes.
column7:
>Shallow snow cover is limiting the avalanche danger at lower elevations in many areas.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Light rain or snow showers should end Saturday morning giving way to mostly cloudy conditions. Moderate ridge top winds should persist Saturday. This should allow for slow settlement of newly formed unstable layers, however some new wind transport along ridges may maintain or continue to build wind slabs below ridges.
Expect to find a wide variety of local snow conditions and plan accordingly with flexibility in mind.

Update Saturday morning - the Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reports a 1"" thick freezing rain crust on Saturday morning throughout the ski area. This will be locking in the snowpack (and cause terrible skiing) and cause a low danger in that area. It is uncertain on Saturday morning how widespread the freezing rain was at Mt Hood. Any areas that have this crust should have a low avalanche danger.

column1: Another warm front will move over the Northwest on Saturday night and Sunday morning. This should cause increasing crest level winds, increasing rain or snow and further rising snow levels.

The rising temperatures and increasing snow densities in the high alpine should help build some new areas of wind slab or storm slab of up to several inches in the high alpine on Saturday night and Sunday morning.

Rain near treeline and below treeline will also load and weaken recent snow in those areas and cause wet snow avalanche conditions. But this should only give possible small wet loose avalanches east of the crest where there was little new snow on Saturday morning.

column2: >Expect to find a wide variety of sno
column3: >w conditions depending on elevation on Sunday. Make new snow pack evaluations as you change elevation if you are in the back country on Sunday.

column1: A break between systems should be seen Sunday afternoon with light rain or snow showers mainly near and west of the crest. This should allow slab layers in the high alpine and wet snow near and below treeline to partly stabilize.

column2: >A cold front should approach from over the Northwest coastal waters on Sunday night. This should cause increasing crest level winds, increasing snow and lowering snow levels Sunday night through Monday morning. This should cause an increasing avalanche danger Sunday night and Monday.

Reports are a bit sparse for the weekend probably primarily due to the poor ski conditions. A couple of most pertinent observations follow. A NWAC observer at Rainy Pass on Saturday reported a lack of crusts in the upper snowpack and no signs of instability via stomping on terrain roll overs and ski cuts. But a NWAC observer just east of Stevens Pass on Saturday reported that the recent snow gave some cracking and small wet loose avalanches.

column1: Quite a change is in store on Monday.

A strong cold front will cross the Northwest on Monday. This will cause strong west crest level winds, moderate to heavy rain changing to snow heaviest near and west of the crest, and cooling and lowering snow levels. These conditions should generally spread from the Olympics and north Cascades Monday early morning to the south Cascades Monday late morning to Mt Hood by Monday afternoon.

During the day on Monday this weather may build some new wind slab in the alpine and some shallower wind slab in near treeline areas on lee slopes. Remember that it can be difficult to determine where wind slab lies but it often has a chalky texture and may be triggered from thin areas near the edge of the slab. Storm slab seems more likely in mostly calmer below treeline areas especially where snowfall rates exceed about an inch per hour.
A high danger is not in the forecast mainly due to the expected cooling trend. But a considerable danger still means dangerous avalanche conditions.

In areas with light wind, where rain changes to snow, and with lower rates of loading, the cooling trend should help bond new snow to old snow and help build right side up conditions with lower density snow nearer the surface. This can mean some good skiing in those types of areas. Underlying wet snow in areas that has it should also begin to refreeze and strengthen.

column2: >Shallow snow cover and shallow new snow will continue
column3: > to limit the avalanche danger at lower elevations

column2: >Tuesday should see the beginning of another extended dry period. Initially on Tuesday freeing levels should be very low with cool air in place following Monday's frontal passage. Winds should diminish to generally light on Tuesday.

column1: This weather should allow for the beginning of recent unstable conditions to settle and slowly stabilize. However, this process my take some time in certain areas, such as higher terrain and where significant wind slab has formed below ridges.
While the overall trend is for lowering danger, triggered avalanches should remain likely in the alpine elevations and possible in the near treeline band.

In areas with light wind, where rain changes to snow, and with lower rates of loading, the cooling trend should help bond new snow to old snow and help build right side up conditions with lower density snow nearer the surface. This can mean some good skiing in those types of areas. Underlying wet snow should also begin to refreeze and strengthen.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Warm wet weather December 13-14th followed by dry weather with high freezing levels helped to form crust layers and stabilize earlier persistent buried weak layers from earlier in December. Most recently a series of fronts over the past four days caused additional precipitation, mostly at moderate freezing levels causing rain or wet heavy snow at mid and lower elevations while depositing 30-60 cm (1-2 ft) of storm snow over most areas along the west slopes and volcanic peaks. This storm cycle while not powerful for northwest standards as caused some recent avalanche activity ranging from wet slabs, loose wet, storm slabs and wind slab releases.

, ' ',

Most recently on Monday 12/23 widespread natural and triggered wind slab releases where seen in the Mt Baker area. The slab releases ranged mostly from 40-60 cm (18-24 inches) and ran long distances with some sympathetic releases triggered remotely. These size 1.5-2 slides released on wind loaded northerly facing slopes below ridges but were extensive. 

, ' ',

A wet slab was reported below Chair Peak in the Alpental Valley Sunday near midday and ran a far distance.

, ' ',

Fluctuating freezing levels over the past several days was followed by a cold front late Monday that brought significant cooling by Monday night and early Tuesday. This cooling has likely helped to strengthen and consolidate previous wet snow or unstable storm slab layers helping to lower the current overall danger.     

, ' ',
column2:
>Watch for areas where a locally deeper snow pack may exist. The most likely areas to find unstable conditions would be on steep generally northerly to east facing terrain below ridges and near or above tree line. These would be the areas most likely to have formed wind slab.  

, '\n\n ',

column1: Mostly sunny days and fair nights are expected except some low clouds or fog in the lower elevation valleys. Winds should remain light with mild temperatures at higher terrain Christmas Day. This should allow for some surface snow melt on sun exposed terrain. Some shallow wet snow conditions may develop by late morning or afternoon on some of these steep sun facing slopes where caution should be exercised.  Previously formed wind slab near ridges should also continue to slowly stabilize.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last significant snowfall over the Mt Hood forecast zone occurred in early December. The dominant weather for December has either been influenced by strong high pressure for dry and mild conditions or weather systems bringing heavy rain at high freezing levels. These conditions have limited the snow accumulations in the Mt Hood area. In addition, a heavy coating of freezing rain blanketed the Mt Hood area on the south side Saturday morning 12/22. This hard crust layer extends above the upper limits of the forecast terrain above 7000 ft. 

, ' ',

The cold front Monday 12/23 caused rain again to high elevations with only a dusting of new snow as it cooled before precipitation ended Monday night.

, ' ',

These conditions are limiting the avalanche potential in most areas of Mt Hood. There were some very strong winds with the most recent frontal passage late Monday and this may have built some shallow areas of wind slab on some lee slopes above tree line.  Dry weather with generally mild conditions were reported at mid and upper locations on Mt. Hood Christmas Day  Mt. Hood Meadows reported some Christmas corn on sun-exposed slopes. 

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

Continued dry, mild and sunny weather should continue on the 26th. Watch for areas where a locally deeper snow pack may exist. The most likely areas to find any unstable conditions would be on steep generally northerly facing terrain below ridges above tree line. These would be the areas most likely to have created hard wind slab.  Isolated loose wet slides may occur on more southerly aspects during the late morning and early afternoon hours.

column2:
>The winter thus far has been dominated either by strong high pressure and dry and mild conditions or weather systems bringing some rain or heavy wet snow at high freezing levels.

, ' ',

Very little recent snow and an overall shallow snowpack are limiting the avalanche potential on most terrain near treeline and below over most east slope areas. Recent weather has been a mix of dry warm and sunny weather with periodic weak frontal passages depositing light amounts of new snow and/or rain. 

, ' ',

A relatively strong cold front moved across the area Monday accompanied by strong to very strong west to northwest crest level winds and deposited 10-20 cm (4-8 inches) of new snow east of the crest. This storm built some wind slab layers on lee slopes probably mostly in the alpine. Many days have passed with some warm temperatures likely allowing for most of these layers to have stabilized.

, ' ',

In the Mt Hood area the main slopes with sufficient snow cover to create a current avalanche potential are on steep shaded northwest through southeast facing slopes mainly above treeline. In most areas, the snowpack consists of firm surface or near surface crusts with shaded and protected terrain maintaining settled old snow with lee slopes possibly maintaining shallow recent wind deposits above treeline.  Slopes exposed to either wind or sun have scoured surface snow exposing hard crust layers near tree line with many areas having very shallow snowcover below treeline.

, ' ',
column3:
>Skiers in the Washington Pass area on Christmas Day reported small areas of triggered wind slab and snowpack whomping in the alpine. 

, '\n\n',
column5:
>Earlier formed persistent weak layers formed periods of clear and cold weather have mostly vanished or not reactive to recent tests as a result of warm periods or rain or heavy wet snow and crust layers. Some of these layers such as surface hoar or facet/crust combinations may persist on steeper shaded terrain, though recent observations are not indicating their presence.

, '\n\n ',

In the Mt Hood area the main slopes with sufficient snow cover to create a current avalanche potential are on steep shaded north through southeast facing slopes mainly above treeline. In most areas, the snowpack consists of firm surface or near surface crusts with possible shallow recent wind deposits.  Slopes exposed to either wind or sun have scoured surface snow exposing hard crust layers near tree line with many areas having very shallow snowcover below treeline.

, ' ',

There has been no recent avalanche activity reported in the Mt Hood area.

After an extended cold and dry period earlier this month that allowed faceting of the near surface snowpack the weather pattern lately has been characterized by stretches of dry weather and infrequent and mild weather systems - very different than Dec 2012.  This pattern has helped stabilize the snowpack as a whole but has done little to help those areas and elevations without much snow.

, ' ',

column1: A weak frontal system should spread light rain and snow over the area tonight along with gradually lowering snow levels overnight. Light precipitation should taper off Tuesday afternoon.

Generally light precipitation and a cooling trend should not greatly increase the avalanche danger on Tuesday.  However, precipitation amounts with this pattern have been poorly handled, so watch for shallow wind and storm slabs mainly in the near and above treeline zones near the Cascade crest. Moderately strong W to NW winds in the alpine overnight may develop new wind slab on lee N thru SE aspects.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

An extended cold and dry period was seen earlier this month that caused faceting of the shallow snowpack at the surface and at the ground in the Cascades probably especially east of the crest.

, ' ',
column2: >The last storm cycle that brought significant snow was about 20-23 December.
column3:
>East of the crest this probably caused a few inches to about a foot of snow in the alpine and some wet snow and rain near and below treeline.

, ' ',

Otherwise the weather since mid December has been characterized by minor wet snow and rain and periods of mild and routinely above freezing temperatures including east of the crest.

, ' ',

Snow reports from NWAC pro observers and on TAY indicate that some of the faceted snow from early December is persisting in the alpine near Washington Pass. Skiers there report isolated areas of shooting cracks and triggered whoomping.

, ' ',

But the periods of mild weather since mid December should have eliminated or de-activated the faceted snow in other areas east of the crest. Most areas should have shallow snow with alternating layers of crusts and rounded grains. Or little if any snow at all.

, ' ',

A weak front is crossing the area on Tuesday. Some light snow or light rain at the higher elevations east of the crest should do little to change conditions.

column1: The ridge which has been around so much over the US west coast this month will build a bit and shift east over the Northwest on Wednesday. This should cause a day of partly cloudy or partly sunny weather and mild above freezing temperatures through the daylight hours in the Olympics and Cascades. This weather and the low sun angle should cause little change in snow conditions.

Watch for the isolated areas of wind slab in the alpine mainly near Washington Pass. For now this will be called wind slab but would be called persistent slab if the underlying faceted snow turns out to be long lived. This is most likely to be triggered in areas where the snow pack is thin and wind affected.
Most other areas should continue with shallow snow with alternating layers of crusts and rounded grains. Or little if any snow at all.
A front will begin to spread clouds and moisture to the area Wednesday night. Some mainly mid and high clouds may reach the Cascade east slopes mainly in the north part Wednesday night.

column1: A change and some uncertainty is in store on Thursday.

A front will begin to reach the Olympics and north Cascades on Thursday afternoon. This should cause increasing southwest winds, increasing rain or snow and lowering snow levels. Snow levels Thursday afternoon should still be high enough to restrict snow to the alpine but up to several inches may be seen there by the end of the daylight hours. Therefore attention in the Olympics and north Cascades will shift to potential new wind and storm slab of several inches in the alpine starting Thursday afternoon. But the cooling and change in most areas from rain to snow should also favor shallow stable snow in many calm areas of the alpine. Rain near treeline or below treeline through Thursday afternoon should not greatly change conditions in those areas.
The uncertainty is due to timing of the storm. If snow arrives sooner or later and snow levels are higher or lower than expected then the expected snow and avalanche conditions would change as well.

The storm will move over the Northwest on Thursday night. This will cause further increasing winds and more snow at further lowering snow levels. The avalanche danger should further increase in the Olympics on Thursday night.

, ' ',

The weather at Mt Hood for most of December has been characterized by minor wet snow and rain and periods of mild and routinely above freezing temperatures.

, ' ',

Reports from the Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol and on TAY mainly indicate stable hard or icy surface crusts, and a consolidated stable snow pack.

, ' ',

Sunny weather but with the low sun angle and very warm temperatures Thursday should promote continued surface crusts in most areas on Mt Hood. 

, ' ',
column2: >The avalanche danger will continue to be especially low at the lower elevations at Mt Hood due to the very shallow

column3: >The strong frontal system should continue to shift southward Thursday night spreading moderate rain or snow at gradually cooling temperatures to most areas, however the front should be weakening as it reaches the Mt Hood area where less overall precipitation is expected.  Very strong crest level WSW winds should shift to WNW are expected in the Mt Hood area overnight and coupled with snowfall at higher elevations, this should build areas of unstable wind slab on lee slopes, mainly from North through Southeast facing slopes in the alpine elevations, causing an increasing avalanche danger Thursday night.

column2: >Rain and snow should turn to snow showers by early Friday with showers ending along with diminishing
column3: > winds. This should begin refreezing old wet snow surfaces and also provide good bonding of new snow to reforming crust layers. This should lead to a gradually decreasing danger. However, previously formed wind slab should persist below ridges on steeper open lee slopes where dangerous avalanche conditions should remain.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The front that cross the area late Thursday through early Friday morning began quite warm and cooled with precipitation and continued to cool throughout. This initially produced rain or heavy wet snow that gradually turned to snow, eventually reaching lower elevations.  This caused a favorable profile of new snow with very good bonding of new snow to the old wet snow surface. The moisture was less by the time the front reached the Mt Hood area with most areas getting about 5-15 cm (2-6 inches) of new snow as of later  Friday. The new snow has formed a good bond to the newly forming crust as reported by several professionals.   

, ' ',

The older snowpack consists mainly of  a mixture of crust layers and consolidated old snow layers.  Recent, mostly dry periods as well as warm temperatures and periods of sunshine have all combined to form a mostly stable old snowpack, void of distinctive weak layers per numerous recent field tests. 

, ' ',

The biggest current concern would be for any newly formed wind slab layers as Thursday's front was accompanied by very strong ridge top winds, initially southwesterly, shifting to northwesterly, though these should be more isolated in extent.  

, ' ',

Snowdepths remain well below normal, generally ranging from 1-2 meters in the alpine regions to less than 1 meter near and below treeline with significantly lower snowdepths below about 4000 feet. 

, ' ',
column2:
>The avalanche danger will continue to be low at the lower elevations due to the low snowpack.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Mostly sunny weather is expected along with gradually diminishing northwest ridgetop winds. Temperatures should begin Saturday very cool and gradually warm through the afternoon, especially at mid and upper elevations. This weather will help to slowly stabilize any previously formed wind slab layers near ridges leading to an overall decreasing danger.

Continue to watch for evidence of recent wind transport as there may be heightened avalanche conditions on specific terrain features, such as steep rollovers below ridges. Continue to evaluate snow and terrain carefully.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

A front crossed the Northwest Thursday afternoon and night. Temperatures began quite warm and cooled during the storm. This initially produced rain or wet snow that gradually turned to snow eventually reaching lower elevations.  Numerous reports indicate this caused a favorable profiles in the new snow and good bonding of new snow to previous wet snow. New snow amounts were greater in the Washington Cascades. The Mt Hood area had about 8 cm (3 inches).

, ' ',

The older snowpack at Mt Hood consists of strong crusts and consolidated old snow layers.  Recent dry and warm periods helped to consolidate and stabilize the older snowpack. 

, ' ',

The biggest current concern would be for any small newly formed wind slab layers as Thursday's front was accompanied by very strong ridge top winds, initially southwesterly, shifting to northwesterly.  The Mt Hood ski patrol reported some very small shallow triggered wind slab near ridges on Friday.

, ' ',

But while winds were strong with wind transport evident in many areas, most recent tests have indicated an overall good stability and most new snow has been non-reactive to ski tests, stability tests and most explosive tests.

, ' ',

Sunny but cool weather will not greatly change conditions on Saturday.

, ' ',

Snowdepths remain well below normal, generally ranging from 1-2 meters in the alpine regions to less than 1 meter near and below treeline with significantly lower snowdepths below about 4000 feet at Mt Hood.

, ' ',
column2:
>The avalanche danger will continue to be low at lower elevations due to the low snowpack.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Sunny and generally much warmer weather will be seen on Sunday with light winds.

This weather will help to further gradually stabilize previous wind slab layers leading to an overall decreasing danger. But continue to watch for signs of wind transported snow near ridges or on specific terrain features such steep rollovers on Sunday especially in the alpine areas.

It will be sunny and warm enough that wet loose avalanches may also be seen on solar aspects. Watch for initial signs of damp loose snow such as wet surface snow deeper than a few inches, rollerballs or natural releases. Wet loose snow avalanche might be most likely in gullies and cirques receiving sun. But solar input is also at its least at this time of year so damp or wet snow should not be extensive.

, ' ',

Sunny weather with warm temperatures is being seen this weekend.

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol has only reported some very small wind slab near ridges in the past couple days. They also report strong surface and mid or base pack crusts and consolidated layers from warm periods in late December.

, ' ',

This should not cause much change in the Mt Hood snowpack. Small isolated wind slab may linger on previous lee slopes near ridges in the alpine. Watch for wind affected snow.
A photo from Saturday of wind affected snow at Hurricane Ridge from NWAC observer Tyler Reid.

, ' ',

Sunny weather with warm temperatures were seen this past weekend. 

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol has only reported some very small wind slab near ridges in the past couple days. They also report strong surface and mid or base pack crusts and consolidated layers from warm periods in late December.

, ' ',

High and mid clouds increased on Monday along with a bit of wind from the SW, and despite the warm temperatures likely kept the snow surface generally firm.  

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

A weak frontal system should spread light rain and snow overnight and continue through Tuesday in the Mt. Hood region.  Some forecast models show up to a 1/2 inch of water with moderate snow levels on Tuesday, and with the heaviest precipitation occurring in the afternoon. New snow should bond well to the old snow surface. Shallow new wind slab may develop on N thru SE aspects, mainly above treeline late in the day.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last significant storm crossed the area last Thursday, initially producing rain or wet snow before transitioning to snow at lower elevations. Upper elevations in the south/central east Cascades received about 5-15 cm (2-6 inches).

, ' ',

Sunny weather was experienced this past weekend through Monday afternoon.  

, ' ',

Avalanche control professionals at Mission Ridge reported a shallow snowpack near and above treeline, with an icy, semi-breakable crust with faceted snowpack underneath. In shallower snowpack areas near the Cascade crest, faceted layers may also be an issue when more load is received. 

, ' ',

New snow amounts received on Tuesday and Tuesday night should have been generally light. 

, ' ',
column2: >The avalanche danger should continue to be low at lower elevations and further away from the crest
column3:
>due to less new snow and a low snowpack.

, '\n\n ',

column1: A stronger system should impact the area on Wednesday, with the heaviest precipitation loading expected in the afternoon and evening hours near the crest.
Increasing S through W ridge-top winds Wednesday afternoon should begin to build new wind slab in the near and above treeline zones on lee NW thru E aspects mainly near the crest.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The storm last Thursday arrived with a favorable cooling trend but due to a warm start only dropped about 3 inches of snow at Mt Hood and Timberline.

, ' ',

Sunny weather with warm temperatures were seen this past weekend. 

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reported older and isolated wind slab above treeline as nonreactive over the last few days. They also report strong surface and mid or base pack crusts and consolidated layers from warm periods in late December through early January. 

, ' ',

New snow, including potentially moderate amounts that fall above 5500-6000 ft Tuesday afternoon through Tuesday night should generally bond well to the old snow surface. New wind slabs on lee N thru SE aspects in the above treeline zone should generally be shallow in depth due to only moderate wind transport. 

, ' ',

Additional loading of 10-25 cm (4-10 inches) new snow has accumulated as of late Wednesday along with strong to very strong crest level winds. This is building new more widespread wind slab layers on lee slopes receiving wind transported snow, especially below ridges and mainly higher elevations above treeline on Mt Hood. 

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

A moderate to strong frontal passage will move across the area Wednesday evening bringing a period of moderate to heavy precipitation through the evening then cooling a shift to moderate showers. The strong westerly flow should maintain showers over the Mt Hood area through Thursday morning at further cooling. This storm should build unstable wind slab layers on many lee slopes near ridges ranging from NW through SE aspects.  The cooling trend by Thursday should help with the new snow profile and limit storm slabs sensitivities but keep an eye for layering using a variety of quick probes and hand shears within the new snow.

Crest level winds should remain strong overnight Wednesday through much of Thursday which will continue to transport falling snow as well as earlier deposited snow thus continuing to build unstable wind slab as well as some cornices.
Less snow and lighter winds as well as continued low snow depths should not appreciably increase the danger at lower elevations.
Another front should begin spreading renewed precipitation over the area late Thursday afternoon or evening to again lead to an increasing danger, but mainly after dark Thursday.

, ' ', ' Jssor Slider End ', ' ',

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Sunny weather with increasingly warm temperatures were seen Sunday and Monday which produced some small loose wet slides on solar aspects and crusts on more varied but not all aspects.

, ' ',

Weak systems began to move to the Northwest about Tuesday with persisting cool offshore surface flow.

, ' ',

A stronger system moved across the Northwest on Wednesday. Snowfall at NWAC sites east of the crest was in the 1-5 inch range. An overall cooling trend Tuesday and Wednesday should have helped to bond new snow to older or crusted surfaces from Sunday and Monday and built mostly favorable new snow profiles. Some shallow storm or wind slab might be expected mainly near ridges.

, ' ',

Mostly light snow showers with minor temperature changes on Thursday should be generally maintaining these conditions.

, ' ',

A difference in the mid pack between the north and south should be seen east of the crest. A NWAC observer in the north at Washington Pass reported a 10-15 inch ski triggered slab avalanche on the 6900 foot northwest slope of Blue Peak col on Tuesday. This was due to a faceted layer in the mid pack.

, ' ',

However in the south part periods of warmer temperatures since late December should be causing generally stable crusts and melt forms in the mid pack.

, ' ',
The forecast for Friday is a bit more complex than usual.

An occluded front should cross the Northwest Thursday afternoon and evening. This should cause continued west to southwest winds and more new snow by Friday morning east of the crest with a slight cooling trend. This should maintain similar conditions through Friday afternoon. Watch for wind slab on lee slopes mainly north to southeast aspects. Storm slab may be possible on more varied aspects. Less snow and lighter winds as well as continued low snow depths should cause less avalanche danger at lower elevations.
Persistent slab may be added to the forecast east of the crest in the north part if additional loading reveals more widespread sensitivity.

The complex part of the forecast comes Friday afternoon and evening which will be a period of rapid change. A very strong front is indicated to cross the Northwest on Friday night. Currently it looks like the strongest winds, heaviest rain or snow and main warming will mostly hold off through Friday afternoon and then begin Friday evening. The avalanche danger should greatly increase Friday night. Beware that if this system and these changes arrive sooner the avalanche danger could rapidly increase Friday afternoon.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Sunny weather with warm temperatures were seen Sunday and Monday. This produced some small loose wet slides on solar aspects and crusts on more varied but not all aspects.

, ' ',

Weak systems began to move to the Northwest about Tuesday with persisting cool offshore surface flow.

, ' ',

A front moved across the Northwest on Wednesday. Snowfall at NWAC sites at Mt Hood was about 10 inches. An overall cooling trend Tuesday and Wednesday helped to bond new snow to older or crusted surfaces from Sunday and Monday and built mostly favorable new snow profiles.

, ' ',

An occluded front crossed the Northwest late on Thursday. NWAC sites at Mt Hood had snowfall in the 5-7 inch range. This snow was generally wet and heavy as elsewhere with remarkably high water equivalents.

, ' ',

Avalanche control results from Mt Hood Meadows today gave local 4 inch to 1 foot slab releases on lee northeast slopes within the new snow but mainly by explosives.

, ' ',

Westerly flow between the departing occluded front and the approaching system is maintaining mostly light snow showers near and west of the crest at fairly steady temperatures on Friday. This should generally maintain slab layers such as the above mainly on lee slopes.

, ' ',

Reports indicate that hoar frost seen early in this week generally didn't survive the changes or is not reactive. Generally stable crusts and melt forms should be found in the mid and base pack in this area.

, ' ',
The active changing pattern will continue over the Northwest through the weekend.
A strong front will cross the Northwest on Friday night causing increasing moderate to heavy rain or snow and rising snow levels. A natural avalanche cycle seems possible on Friday night.

Stormy weather due to strong orographic west flow and heavy showers with lowering snow levels should be seen Saturday. The main concern during the day Saturday should be rapid snow loading and deep storm slab building especially in the alpine and near treeline and then to below treeline on many or most slopes. Rapid snow loading is generally accepted to mean more than 1' of snow per hour. Natural and triggered avalanche should be likely on Saturday.

Strong SW winds will veer to W behind the front later Saturday morning.  Expect rapid wind loading Friday night and throughout the day Saturday.  Strong winds should easily develop wind slab on lee slopes...and due to the strong winds wind loading will occur further downslope than during a more moderate event.
Remember the danger ratings and icons are for the daylight hours. The avalanche danger should still be limited at the lowest elevations by shallow snow and terrain and vegetation.

, '\n\n',
column4: >During a wet, warm and windy Friday night, rain crept up to about 4500' in the north, 5000-5500' in the central Cascades and 6000' in the south, a cold front came through Saturday morning, dropping snow levels down to around 3000-3500' Saturday.  Heavy showers and strong west winds (Mission Ridge reported over 100 mph at the upper station), along with up to another 0.5 inch of water through the daylight hours likely built new unstable wind slab in the near and above treeline zones.
column5:
>Expect wind-scoured windward slopes above tree-line (see report below). The strong convective nature of the showers today and this evening with varying precipitation rates likely introduced instabilities within the shallow new storm snow as well.  

, ' ',

NWAC observer Tom Curtis reported scoured slopes on SE through SW aspects around 6000 ft near Blewett Pass on Thursday.  A pit on a wind loaded NE aspect revealed a snowpack of ice layers, melt forms and rounds, with rounding facets below a near surface crust the only layer of concern prior to new wind loading with this weekend's storm.   Mission Ridge avalanche professionals reported no new results through Friday morning.    

, ' ',

column1: Showers and winds should briefly ease overnight before a warm front beings to spread additional rain and snow over the area on Sunday. The timing of the heaviest precipitation is uncertain on Sunday, but snow levels should stay cool through late morning before rising gradually in the afternoon.

column2: >The avalanche danger will remain elevated through Sunday, with danger increasing strongly in the afternoon as denser storm and wind slab develop. Choose conservatively on Sunday
column3: new storm snow from Saturday will not have had much time to settle,  be aware for wind loaded slopes well off of ridges onto lee N thru SE slopes, be ready for warming temperatures to create a unfavorable a new snow profile later Sunday along for the potential for wet snow avalanches late in the day at lower elevations. Also, give new cornices a wide berth as they have had neither time to settle and will also be subject to warming late in the day.

column2: >The avalanche danger should still be limited on scoured windward slopes and at the lowest elevations by shallow snow and terrain and vegetation.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The first significant storm cycle of 2014, and more recently in the last 3 weeks, is coming to a close with some impressive numbers. With the first and weakest system arriving on Tuesday and carrying through Sunday afternoon, approximate amounts of water at NWAC Mt. Hood stations are 8 and 9.5 inches of water at Mt. Hood Meadows and Timberline respectively. In the last 36 hours, about 2 feet of snow has fallen at Mt. Hood stations.   

, ' ',
column2:
>Early on in the storm cycle an overall cooling trend Wednesday through Thursday helped new snow bond well to older crusted surfaces and built mostly favorable new snow profiles.  An occluded front crossed the Northwest late Thursday producing light amounts of dense snow.  Avalanche control results from Mt Hood Meadows Friday morning gave local 4"" to 1' slab releases on lee northeast slopes within the new snow but mainly by explosives.

, '\n\n',

During a warm and windy Friday night, freezing levels crept up to about 6000' but rain mostly avoided Mt. Hood. A strong cold front Saturday morning plunged snow levels to 3500' Saturday.  Heavy showers and strong west winds
column3:
> mainly above treeline continued Saturday night along with a cooling trend.  Heavy loading and a slow warming trend continued through the day Sunday, with rain mixing in mid-day up to around 4000 feet.  Mt. Hood Meadows avalanche patrol reported widespread 6 -10"" soft slab releases with ski cuts and explosives. Larger 3' releases on wind loaded slopes released with only explosives.  Shallow wet loose slides began mid-day below 4000' due to rain and warming.  No reports were available from about 6600 feet.  

, '\n\n ',

column1: The steady stream of warm frontal precipitation will lift north Sunday night with only very light additional loading expected through the day. Westerly winds will strong be in the alpine, but additional wind loading should also be on the decrease due less available snow for transport and warmer temperatures. The greatest avalanche concerns will be from recent storm and wind loaded slopes that have not settled.  Considerable Danger will be in effect on Monday near and above treeline mainly for the lee slopes that are still sensitive due to the likelihood of human triggered slides.  Continue to choose your terrain and aspect wisely!

column2: >Wet-loose avalanches are possible mainly near and below 5000 feet where above freezing temperatures and light rain may cause pin-wheeling and loose wet slides.

column5: >Precipitation should end by early Tuesday as skies clear and freezing levels climb.  Moderate northwest crest level winds should gradually ease through the day Tuesday.  This weather will help to settle and consolidate the large recent storm snow deposits and lead to a slowly stabilizing snowpack.  However warming and sunshine by late Tuesday may lead to some shallow wet snow conditions and possible loose-wet slides on steeper solar aspects.

>At elevations above treeline, earlier formed wind slab should be somewhat slower to stabilize so continue to evaluate snow and terrain carefully.  These earlier formed wind slabs near ridges in the alpine region should remain the greatest concern, most probably on north through southeast facing slopes.  Rather large wind slab releases may trigger more deeply buried weaknesses near or above old crust interfaces and this may lead to very large slides, though natural or triggered slides should become less likely and more stubborn to trigger, it remains a time to be extra cautious.

Hood Meadows and Timberline respectively. Some 4 ft of storm snow has been deposited over the five days ending Monday at Mt. Hood stations.

column2:

Hood Meadows avalanche patrol reported widespread 6 -10"" soft slab releases with ski cuts and explosives. Larger 3' releases on wind loaded slopes released with only explosives.  Shallow wet loose slides began mid-day below 4000' due to rain and warming.  No reports were available from about 6600 feet. 

, '\n\n',
column4:
>Most recently the patrol at Mt Hood Meadows on Tuesday released a rather large wind slab from explosive control.  This slide released at about 6200 ft on a NNE facing slope with a crown height of 4 ft and propagated about 300 ft wide and ran about 700 ft to the bottom of the path.  The interface was believed to be a storm layer from late last week between warm and cold snow layers.  While it may not always be a good indicator of human triggered potential, it should give one pause to consider the terrain you'll be travelling in over the next few days.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Mostly sunny weather, mild temperatures and light to moderate crest level winds are expected Wednesday.  This weather should allow for earlier formed weak layers to continue to settle and stabilize as well as earlier formed wind and storm slabs.  This weather will also help to consolidate the large recent storm snow deposits and lead to a slowly stabilizing snowpack.
However warming and sunshine may lead to wet snow conditions and possible loose-wet slides on steeper solar aspects.

At elevations above treeline, earlier formed wind slab should be somewhat slower to stabilize so evaluate snow and terrain carefully and identify features of concern, such as lee slopes below ridges, cornice features, or steep break overs on slopes.  These earlier formed wind slabs near ridges in the alpine region should remain the greatest concern, most probably on north through southeast facing slopes.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Weather:

, ' ',

A nearly week long major storm cycle ended about Tuesday morning.

, ' ',

This first part delivered heavy snow with about 3 feet of snowfall for a 4 day period ending Sunday morning at NWAC sites at Mt Hood.

, ' ',

Then a strong warming period with wet snow and rain was seen with rain or water equivalents in the 2.5-3.6 inch range for 2 days ending Tuesday morning at NWAC sites at Mt Hood.

, ' ',

Avalanches:

, ' ',

An avalanche cycle was seen in the Washington Cascades mainly Sunday during the warming period as increasing wet heavy snow and then rain built an upside down snowpack and loaded underlying colder and sometimes preserved lower density layers. But mainly new surface crusts layers and little avalanche activity were reported by the Meadows Ski Patrol.

, ' ',
column2: >Warming and additional rain was seen on Monday. Wet or s
column4:
> warming produced wet snow avalanches on solar slopes in the Washington Cascades. But again no reports were seen of significant wet snow avalanches at Mt Hood.

, ' ',

Consolidation and a new surface crust from Tuesday night has helped to improve stability in all areas by Wednesday. The Mt Hood Meadows patrol reports that winds and some high clouds are also limited warming and sun effects on Wednesday. Snow pit tests at Mt Hood Meadows on a northeast slope at 6500 feet did not find significant weak layers on Wednesday.

, ' ',
column6: > the west slopes of the Cascades including Mt Hood a generally favorable mid and lower snowpack exists, even if well below seasonal norms, and is expected to consist of crust layers and melt form crystals from warm periods in late December and early January.

column1: Light winds, sunny weather and warm temperatures should be seen on Thursday. But the sun is still pretty weak less than a month after the solstice.

This weather should mainly cause layers to further consolidate and further stabilize. Watch for lingering cornices and areas of wind slab on lee slopes mainly in the alpine. This should be mainly on north to southeast facing slopes.
Warming and sunshine may lead to loose wet snow conditions on steep solar aspects.

Hood and added several inches of water weight to the snowpack. A fair amount of westerly wind accompanied the event from Friday through Monday and redistributed new snow onto lee slopes. The tail end of the storm cycle from Sunday afternoon through early Tuesday was accompanied by a warming trend that brought rain to mid elevations.

column1: Solar influences will drive the avalanche danger on Friday. Be aware of quickly softening surface snow in the late morning and afternoon on solar aspects. Natural pin-wheels or sinking in more than ankle deep means it is time to get off and out of the way of steeper southerly slopes at all elevations. Still approach wind loaded slopes with caution, isolated wind slab may linger on N thru SE aspects near and above treeline zones.

Widespread cornice growth was not reported during the most recent storm cycle, but be aware that local areas with cornices will be subject to the warming and sunshine and have an increased hazard during the day.

column1: Temperatures should warm Monday as freezing levels climb under high pressure back up by 5 to 10 degrees from Sunday.  Plenty of sunshine, warming temperatures and light winds Monday should allow for gradual surface snow melt on steeper solar aspects during the late morning and afternoon, especially mid and higher elevations.

column2: >Be aware of quickly softening surface snow in the late morning through afternoon hours on solar aspects. Natural pin-wheels or sinking in more than ankle deep means it is time to get off that slope and out of the way of steeper southerly slopes and avoid terrain traps.
>Continue to approach wind loaded slopes with caution, isolated wind slab may linger on N thru SE aspects near and above treeline zones.

, ' ',
column2: >An avalanche cycle was seen in the Washington Cascades mainly on Sunday, 12 January during the warming period, however,
column4:

column5: >Wednesday through today featured increasing sun and warm temperatures. Snow surfaces varied from sun softened solar aspects, wind board on lee slopes to firm crusts and even ice on wind-scoured slopes. Snow pit tests at Mt Hood Meadows on a northeast lee slope at 6500 feet did not find significant weak layers on last Wednesday.
column7:
>Steeper solar aspects were likely the biggest recent source of avalanche danger.  East winds on the lower mountain helped keep temperatures cool and snow locked down.  A low sun angle and cooler temperatures should have diminished the possibility of loose-wet releases on solar aspects below tree-line. 

, ' ',

For the Mt Hood area a generally favorable mid and lower snowpack exists and is expected to consist of crust layers and melt form crystals from earlier in the season.

column1: Clear weather should cause a good refreeze of snow surfaces on Monday night.

Then a minor increase in winds, some high clouds and cooler temperatures should be seen on Tuesday. This should result in less surface snow melting, firmer surface snow and less likelihood of wet loose snow avalanches on Tuesday. Continue to watch for
column2: >quickly softening surface snow in the late morning through afternoon hours on solar aspects. Natural pin-wheels or sinking in more than ankle deep means it is time to get off that slope and away from steeper solar slopes.
>Continue to approach previous lee or wind loaded slopes with caution since isolated wind slab may linger on N thru SE aspects near and above treeline zones.

column1: A very weak front should cross the Northwest on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. Little if any precipitation should be seen and there should be no big changes in snow conditions.
Clouds should decrease on Wednesday with cooler temperatures than the past couple days.

Small areas of wind slab will be the only listed concern for Mt Hood but will be indicated as unlikely. This will be for north to southeast slopes above tree line. Such layers would likely require large triggers such as a falling cornice or a snow mobile.

Wet loose snow avalanches seem unlikely on Wednesday give all the recent consolidation, recent wet loose avalanche activity, cooler temperatures and potential high clouds and will not be listed as a concern. Avoid steep solar aspects or gullies in the sun if you see surface snow there deeper than a few inches or natural wet loose avalanches.

column1: The main concern Saturday should be areas of shallow wet snow developing on sun exposed slopes, especially below rock outcrops or cliff areas.

Freezing levels and temperatures should remain warm Saturday with weakening winds.  Mid and higher terrain away from the lower Cascade crest or passes will have better chances of small wet loose avalanches.  Avoid steep solar aspects or gullies in the sun if you see surface snow there deeper than a few inches or natural wet loose avalanches.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last storm cycle to impact the Northwest was about 10-14 of January.  The storm produced about 3 feet of snow at NWAC sites at Mt Hood. The tail end of the storm cycle 12-14 January brought a warming trend that caused rain at low and mid elevations and upside down heavy dense snow at higher elevations. The main resulting avalanche cycle was seen in the Washington Cascades with surprisingly little activity at Mt Hood.

, ' ',

Mostly sunny weather and warm temperatures have been seen the past 11 days. This has mainly caused snow pack consolidation and stabilizing with strong surface crusts on most slopes especially at Mt Hood.
column2: >A generally favorable mid and lower snowpack of crust layers and melt form crystals should also be seen in this area. Firm thick surface crusts and stable conditions and no recent avalanches have been reported by the Mt Hood Meadows patrol.
column3:
>The avalanche danger is low at lower elevations where there is little snow and and ample terrain and vegetation anchors.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Another sunny warm day with light winds should be seen on Sunday. There should be little change in snow conditions.

Concerns on Sunday should be very limited. Wet loose avalanches seem unlikely on Sunday due to recent consolidation, past activity, limited solar input and increasing surface crusts. But avoid steep solar aspects or gullies in the sun if you seen natural wet loose avalanches or wet surface snow deeper than a few inches.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The last storm cycle to impact the Northwest was about 10-14 of January. The main resulting avalanche cycle was seen in the Washington Cascades with surprisingly little activity at Mt Hood.

, ' ',

Mostly sunny weather and warm temperatures have been seen the past 11 days at Mt Hood. This has caused snow pack consolidation with stabilizing surface crusts on most slopes at Mt Hood. Old slab layers on lee shaded slopes should be mostly stabilized.
column2: >A generally favorable mid and lower snowpack of crust layers and melt form crystals should also be generally seen at Mt Hood. Firm thick surface crusts and stable conditions and no recent avalanches have lately been reported by the Mt Hood Meadows patrol. A report on TAY for 24 January also seems to confirm these conditions.
column3:
>The avalanche danger is especially low on many south slopes at lower elevations where there is little snow and and ample terrain and vegetation anchors.

, '\n\n ',

column1: High clouds should increase on Monday at Mt Hood. There should be little change in snow conditions.

Concerns again on Monday at Mt Hood should be very limited. Very small areas of old slab layers may linger on some lee shaded slopes above treeline. Such layers would likely require large triggers such as a fall cornice or snowmobile. Use normal caution on steep lee shaded slopes.

Wet loose avalanches seem even less likely at Mt Hood on Monday due to recent consolidation, increasing high clouds and cooler temperatures and will not be listed as a concern on Monday. But avoid steep solar aspects or gullies in the sun if you seen natural wet loose avalanches or wet surface snow deeper than a few inches.

Local non-avalanche hazards:  Thinner than usual crevasse bridges have been noted in the Washington Cascades. Don't assume that crevasses have the usual relatively thick bridges during this so far shallow snow season.
, ' ', ' Jssor Slider Begin ', ' ', ' You can move inline styles to css file or css block. ', ' ',

, ' ', ' Jssor Slider End ', ' ',

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Nearly 2 weeks has passed since any rain, snow or other form of precipitation has graced the Pacific Northwest.  This period has been remarkable for the abundant sunshine and high freezing levels seen during the stretch.  Strong temperature inversions were common, and periods of moderate easterly flow kept the Cascade passes cooler and cloudier than elsewhere in the Cascades.  Crowns are still visible from the last major storm cycle in mid-January which produced
column2:
>storm slab avalanches up to size D3 on wind loaded aspects near and above treeline.  Numerous natural wet-loose avalanches were seen on solar aspects immediately following the cycle.  Since then, solar aspects have experienced natural pinwheeling with softening of the upper snowpack during the day but natural wet-loose slides have been confined to steeper slopes, especially near rocky terrain.  Most recently,  NWAC observer Dallas Glass reported a natural size 1.5 wet loose avalanche Sunday at 4500 ft on a SE slope of Lichtenburg Mtn near Stevens Pass.   

, '\n\n',

Snow surfaces across the region are highly variable, with firm conditions at low and mid elevations with a rain crust reported on many non-solar aspects, breakable crusts in the trees, melt-freeze crusts on exposed solar aspects softening to corn in the afternoons and wind affected snow on higher lee slopes. Recycled powder likely exists on some sheltered northerly aspects, but has not been widely reported.
column3: > A generally favorable mid and lower snowpack of crust layers and melt form crystals should still be an appropriate
column5:
>The avalanche danger is especially low on many south slopes and at lower elevations where there is little snow and ample terrain and vegetation anchors. (see photo below from Hurricane Ridge)

, ' ',

Isolated areas of cold slab layers are still surviving on some lee shaded slopes where some faceting has been occurring in the upper snowpack.  It's been about a week since NWAC observers at Hurricane and Nason Ridge near Stevens Pass reported moderate or hard test results with sudden fractures. However, extended column tests did not indicate a tendency for propagation and there have been no known avalanches on these layers. Keep these potentially isolated layers of concern in mind moving forward this week.

, ' ',

Surface hoar growth continues to be widely reported this week, reaching into the above tree-line zone and with significant growth in the more sheltered areas, up to 20-30 mm thick!   Also keep these layers in mind as we receive new loading this week. 

, ' ',

/>

, ' ',

East facing terrain near Hurricane Ridge, Photo by Katy Reid 1-25-14

, ' ',
column9:
/>

, ' ',

Test pit profile shows crusts and moist 1F snow with no layers of concern on SW Aspect @ 5000 ft near Artist Point, Mt. Baker, Photo by Jeff Hambelton 1-27-14. 

, ' ',
column11:
/>

, ' ',

Open crevasse on Silverstar Glacier in North Cascades, Photo by Jeff Ward 1-23-14

, ' ',
column13:
>On January 13th a heavy local freezing rain event occurred in the Snoqualmie Pass area above about 4500 feet, covering the surface with about a 2-3 inch ice crust. This crust should break down over time but a fall on a slope on this surface could result in a long and dangerous ride!  

, ' ',

Additionally, guides in the North Cascades have noted some thin snow bridges spanning crevasses on lower glaciers. Assume that crevasses do not have their usual and relatively thick snow bridges during this lower than normal snow season.

, ' ',

column1: Generally light rain and snow, and perhaps mixed precipitation in the Cascade Passes should add little load to the existing snow surfaces or effect the overall avalanche danger on Tuesday.  Relatively moderate snow levels should destroy recently buried surface hoar at lower elevations away from the Cascade passes but may allow these layers in other areas to become buried and problematic during future loading.

, ' ',
column4: >Nearly 2 weeks of dry weather came to an end <span class=""aBn"" data-term=""goog_1161543906"" style=""border-bottom-width: 1px
column13:
>Tuesday. This period had been remarkable for the abundant sunshine and high freezing levels seen during the stretch. Strong temperature inversions were common, and periods of moderate easterly flow kept the exposed lower and mid slopes of Mt. Hood cooler than the free-air freezing levels at times. Little direct-action avalanches were seen directly after the storm cycle in mid-January or wet-loose activity during the more recent warm weather. Generally firm conditions have been reported on Mt. Hood, with steeper solar aspects softening to corn in the afternoon over the past weekend up to 10K feet.    

, '\n\n',
column16:
>A generally favorable mid and lower snowpack of crust layers and melt form crystals should be an appropriate regional description. The avalanche danger is especially low on many south slopes at lower elevations where there is little snow and ample terrain and vegetation anchors.

, '\n\n',
column19: >Although surface hoar growth likely occurred during the dry stretch on many non-solar aspects below and near treeline it is unlikely to survive rain to around 7k ft <span class=""aBn"" data-term=""goog_1161543907"" style=""border-bottom-width: 1px

column4: >Moderate to heavy rain or snow early <span class=""aBn"" data-term=""goog_1161543909"" style=""border-bottom-width: 1px

column31: >on Wednesday. Strong west to southwest winds throughout the day will continue to transport and build increasingly large wind slabs down wind of ridges above tree-line early in the day and near tree-line during
column40: >Wednesday afternoon.  Newly formed wind slab found on lee N thru E aspects should be the greatest avalanche concern
