Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

A two week spell of mild and dry weather was officially broken as a strong front finally moved across the area early Wednesday.  The dry stretch produced strong temperature inversions, periods of moderate cool easterly flow in the passes and warm sunshine at higher elevations.  The main avalanche activity over this period was limited to generally small natural wet-loose slides confined to steeper slopes, especially near rocky terrain. 

, ' ',

Snow surfaces across the region were highly variable prior to the latest storms arrival, typified by firm conditions at low and mid elevations with a smooth rain or melt freeze crust on many non-solar aspects (the source of many sliding accidents over the weekend), breakable crusts in the trees, rougher melt-freeze crusts on exposed solar aspects and wind affected snow on higher lee slopes.  The low snow amounts on many south slopes and at lower elevations and ample terrain and vegetation anchors remain a factor to reduce the overall danger in those areas.  

, ' ',

Of more important note is the extensive surface hoar growth that has been reported during the last week with generally shallow growth at Cascade pass levels but reaching into the above tree-line zone and with significant growth in the more sheltered areas near the Cascade crest up to 20-30 mm thick!   NWAC observers in the Rainy Pass area just east of Stevens Pass below treeline
column10:
>on Tuesday reported a light rimed crust capping nearly 30mm of surface hoar and preserving this layer for additional loading (see photo and video below). Shallower surface hoar was found as they traveled to near 5500 ft on similar gladed open shaded slopes.  WSDOT avalanche professionals at Stevens Pass reported a shallower and less worrisome layer of surface hoar affected by moderate east winds.  

, ' ',

In addition, a locally very hard and smooth freezing rain crust was preserved in the passes during cold east winds at the beginning of the recent storm.  The initial cold snow in the passes formed a poor bond to the crust with warmer snow being deposited late in the storm.  This formed very sensitive slab releases as reported by patrol at Alpental Wednesday afternoon with many slides releasing upon approach to slopes, some sympathetic and remote releases as well. Most of these slides were reported from about 4000-4800'. This is creating locally very dangerous avalanche conditions in the Stevens and Snoqualmie Passes.    

, ' ',
column13: >NWAC observers video 1-28-14 from Rainy Pass
column22:
/>

, ' ',

Surface hoar with thin rimed crust near Rainy Pass @ 4600 ft 1-28-14, Photo by Jeff Ward and Dallas Glass

, ' ',
column27:
>Test pit profile shows stable mix of crusts and moist 1F snow in the upper and mid snowpack on a SW Aspect @ 5000 ft near Artist Point, Mt. Baker, Photo by Jeff Hambelton 1-27-14.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Generally decreasing light to occasionally moderate snow showers at further cooling temperatures along with diminishing winds are expected Thursday.   The cool temperatures should preserve any existing weak layers within storm snow as well as layers such as buried surface hoar or weak bonding between old and new snow.
Future avalanche concerns:  Buried surface hoar will most likely be preserved near the Cascade passes due to a light freezing rain crust formed
column10: >Tuesday and at higher sheltered elevations near the Cascade crest that did not see rain. This avalanche concern should be most likely in the below treeline area in the Snoqualmie Pass area and will present challenging terrain management for backcountry travelers moving forward in the week as additional loading stresses this recently buried weak layer. Look for shooting cracks and listen for whumpfing even in low angle terrain as a clear sign that this persistent weak layer exists and may extend into avalanche terrain.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Pretty heavy rain and now snow has recently been seen at Mt Hood. NWAC sites at Mt Hood indicate about 5-10 inches of new snow ending Thursday morning. Several more inches is likely Thursday night.

, ' ',

The change from rain to snow and a cooling trend have helped to bond new snow to old crust surfaces. But new areas of wind slab should be possible on lee slopes and storm slab should be possible on sheltered slopes by the end of Thursday night. Watch for signs of wind transported snow mainly above and near tree line. Storm slab will most likely in sheltered areas if there is rapid loading on Thursday night. Rapid loading is generally accepted to be more than an inch of snow per hour.

, ' ',

At least the mid and lower snowpack consists mainly of stable crusts and melt form crystal layers. The low snow amounts on many south slopes and at low elevations and ample terrain and vegetation anchors are limiting the avalanche danger in those areas.

, ' ',

Here is a video and a photo from Wednesday from the Timberline area by NWAC observer Tom Curtis.

If you intend to visit any part of the Washington Cascades be sure to read the NWAC avalanche forecast for that area. A potentially  dangerous persistent hoar frost layer has been buried in parts of the Washington Cascades.

column1: Light snow showers should end Friday morning. Partial clearing should be seen Friday afternoon and night with continued cool temperatures.
There should be little change in snow conditions on Friday.

New wind slab is likely to remain on lee slopes above tree line on Friday. Watch for signs of wind transported snow above treeline. Temporary storm slab may survive on Friday on sheltered slopes near and below tree line on Friday. Check weather station data or watch for snow accumulations of greater than about an inch per hour.

Remember to read the NWAC avalanche forecast if you intend to visit any part of the Washington Cascades since a potentially  dangerous persistent hoar frost layer has been buried in parts of that area.

, ' ',

Pretty heavy rain and now snow has recently been seen at Mt Hood. NWAC sites at Mt Hood indicate about 1-1.5 feet of new snow ending Friday morning for the recent storm.

, ' ',

The change from rain to snow and a cooling trend should have helped to bond new snow to old crust surfaces and built generally right side up new snow layers. But temporary storm weaknesses will be possible in the new snow. New areas of wind slab are possible on lee slopes mainly near and above treeline. New areas of storm slab will be possible on sheltered slopes near and below treeline.

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadows patrol reported easy failures in the new snow layers on a northeast slope at 6600 feet on Friday morning.

, ' ',

At least the mid and lower snowpack consists mainly of crusts and melt form crystal layers which have generally not been reactive to to snow pit tests. Low snow amounts are limiting the avalanche danger on many south slopes and at low elevations due to terrain and vegetation anchors.

column1: Partly or mostly cloudy cool weather should be seen at Mt Hood on Saturday.
Layers and snow from the recent storm should slightly stabilize on Saturday.
Decreasing areas of wind slab from the recent storm may linger on lee slopes above tree line on Saturday. Watch for signs of wind transported snow mainly above treeline.
Temporary but decreasing areas of storm slab may survive until Saturday on sheltered slopes near and below tree line.
Be sure to read the avalanche forecasts for the Washington Cascades due to potential dangerous hoar frost layers that have been buried in parts of that area.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The most recent storm cycle began last Tuesday night with rising snow levels and rain above 6000 feet for the Olympics before transitioning to snow and colder temperatures. Wind was less of a factor with this event with a more even distribution of storm snow and a general lack of wind slab.   

, ' ',

NWAC observers Tyler and Katy Reid in the Hurricane Ridge Friday and Saturday reported good snow conditions on northerly aspects with a light crust forming on solar aspects over the last 2 days.  New surface hoar growth up to 10 mm was observed well in the near-treeline zone Saturday (see photo below). Skiers triggered unconsolidated new snow into size 1-2 dry loose avalanches on northerly aspects near tree-line Friday. Large wet loose slides were reported around 6000 feet on the E-SE slopes of Mt. Angeles Saturday. No information has been received from the above treeline zone deeper in the Olympics. 

, ' ',
column3:
/>

, ' ',

Recently formed Surface Hoar with graupel from showers on 2-1-14 Hurricane Ridge area, N aspect @ 5200 ft by Seth Waterfall

, ' ',
column4:
>Regionally the avalanche danger is lower near Hurricane Ridge than in the Washington Cascades where a more diverse snowpack exists. See the Cascades forecast if traveling.   

, ' ',

The mid and lower snowpack west of the crest consists mainly of crusts and melt form crystal layers which have generally not been reactive to to snow pit tests. Low snow amounts are limiting the avalanche danger on many south slopes and at low elevations due to terrain and vegetation anchors.

, ' ',

column1: Cool temperatures followed by an increase in clouds and light snow showers Sunday afternoon will do little to change the current avalanche danger. Loose dry releases from the new storm snow should be the most widespread avalanche concern today on non-solar aspects near and above tree-line.  A mid-level temperature inversion (of warmer temperatures) on Saturday may have allowed unconsolidated snow to become more slab-like by the end of yesterday. Continue to approach lee slopes, especially non-solar aspects near tree-line with caution and test for the bond between the old and new storm interface before committing to the slope in question.
, ' ', ' Jssor Slider Begin ', ' ', ' You can move inline styles to css file or css block. ', ' ',

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Heavy rain was followed by snow with the most recent storm over Mt Hood. NWAC sites at Mt Hood indicate about 1-1.5 feet of new snow ending Friday morning.  The new snow followed several inches of rain that reached into the above treeline zone on Mt. Hood.

, ' ',

The change from rain to snow and a cooling trend has helped to bond new snow to old crust surfaces and built generally right side up new snow layers. While storm snow instabilities should be settled out, areas of wind slab are still possible on lee slopes mainly near and above treeline. 

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadows patrol reported easy failures in the new snow layers on a northeast slope at 6600 feet on Friday morning but no new reports of instability on Saturday.  A large natural slab avalanche was visible around 10,500 feet on the Newton Headwall on a NE aspect that likely released during or after the storm cycle ended.  Of interest was the new surface hoar growth on sastrugi on east aspects above treeline up to 7000 feet reported by the Mt. Hood Meadows ski patrol.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Very cold temperatures this week have produced strong temperature gradients in the upper portion of the snowpack.  See WSDOT Snoqualmie pit profile below for an example of the steep temperature gradient in the upper 10 cm and a more moderate temperature gradient (~ 10C/m) over the top meter.  The strong temperature gradient has lead to near surface faceting and a breakdown on recently buried crusts.  The preservation of weak layers buried about a week ago from the last storm cycle in and near the Cascade Passes continues during this cold spell as well.  Public and NWAC observers continue to report buried surface hoar on sheltered non-solar aspects in the below tree-line zone, most widely reported near the Cascade passes and just east of the crest under about 25-50 cm of the most recent and settled storm snow.   However, near surface facets on or just above the late Jan crust show the most sensitivity in snowpack tests with high quality shears but low sensitivity to ski triggering and have not been linked to any recent natural avalanches.  These layers are not likely on solar aspects and the most recent storm snow has been reported as better bonded to the old crust on solar aspects.  A thin sun crust has formed on some steeper solar slopes.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

A strong storm at the end of January brought rain up to mid elevations and was followed with a cooling trend.  With the exception of a day or so of sensitive wind slab following the storm, little avalanche activity was reported. 

, ' ',

This week Mt. Hood received more snow than their northerly neighbors...and a fair amount of wind.  Very cold winds kept the snow dry and light in wind protected areas. Moderate east winds affected elevations below 5000 feet through Thursday.  Southwest winds above 6000 feet redistributed snow onto more traditional lee aspects forming new wind slab.  Timberline and Mt. Hood Meadows reported 6 and 8 inches of new low density snow respectively through Friday morning...with a few more inches through Friday afternoon.  

, ' ',

Mt. Hood Meadows pro patrol reported sensitive wind slabs above tree-line up to 7000 feet on lee aspects, mainly N thru SE.  Wind slabs generally ranged from 6-12"" and were sensitive to both skier triggers and explosives.  While the wind slab was relatively soft...the hardness change to the underlying snow surface produced poor bonding with the continuing cold temperatures.  Strong SW winds were forecast higher on Mt. Hood Friday...increasingly the likelihood of hard wind slabs that were thicker further up on the mountain.   Meadows patrol also reported loose dry avalanches to be entraining a fair amount of new snow on steeper slopes.  Enough new snow was entrained to present a danger if caught and carried into a terrain trap.  

, ' ',
column2:

, ' ',

A strong storm at the end of January brought rain up to mid elevations and was followed with a cooling trend.  With the exception of a day or so of sensitive wind slab following the storm, little avalanche activity was reported. 

, ' ',

This week Mt. Hood received more snow than their northerly neighbors...and a fair amount of wind.  Very cold winds kept the snow dry and light in wind protected areas. Moderate east winds affected elevations below 5000 feet through Thursday.  Southwest winds above 6000 feet redistributed snow onto more traditional lee aspects forming new wind slab.  Timberline and Mt. Hood Meadows reported 6 and 8 inches of new low density snow respectively through Friday morning...with an additional 12-16 inches by Saturday afternoon.  

, ' ',

Mt. Hood Meadows pro patrol reported widespread sensitive wind slabs above and near treeline both Friday and again Saturday on lee aspects, mainly N thru SE.  Wind slabs generally ranged from 1-2 ft and were sensitive to both skier triggers and explosives.  While the wind slab was relatively soft...the hardness change to the underlying snow surface produced poor bonding with the continuing cold temperatures.  A period of strong SW winds early Saturday have increased the likelihood of some hard wind slabs higher up on the mountain.   Meadows patrol also reported loose dry avalanches to be entraining a fair amount of new snow on steeper slopes.  Enough new snow was entrained to present a danger if caught and carried into a terrain trap.

, ' ',

A strong storm at the end of January brought rain up to mid elevations and was followed with a cooling trend.  With the exception of a day or so of sensitive wind slab following the storm, little avalanche activity was reported. 

, ' ',

The Mt Hood area has received over 2 feet of new snow over the past three days which is significantly greater than what fell in the WA Cascades.  There were also periods of very strong winds over the past few days and this has built rather large and sensitive wind slab conditions especially above tree line but also near tree line as well as reported by Mt Hood Meadows pro patrol. These wind slabs have built over cold low density snow or weak faceted snow.  Over the past three days the pro patrol have reported

The heavy rate of snowfall late Saturday through early Sunday should build more widespread denser storm slabs over a variety of weak surface snow layers or poorly bond to exposed hard crust layers as well as build large wind slab on lee slopes.  These conditions should maintain very dangerous avalanche conditions, especially above treeline where travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended.

column1: A frontal system should spread increasing rain and snow at gradually rising freezing levels Monday along with strong ridgetop winds. This weather system should cause a significant increase in the danger through the day Monday.  Given the variety of weak surface snow conditions, including surface hoar, weak near surface faceted snow or previously deposited weak low density snow any significant storm snow should lead to sensitive slab avalanches as dense cohesive surface snow becomes effective for slab avalanche propagation.

These storm or wind slabs should develop from increasing density storm snow and also from wind transported wind slab.  Watch for more significant storm and/or wind transported snow by Monday as avalanche danger may increase rapidly if loaded by significant new snow.

Travel in avalanche terrain near and above treeline is not recommended Monday.  Avoid any steep open terrain being loaded by significant storm snow. Even a small wind slab in the wrong terrain, i.e. above cliffs or very steep slopes, could have unintended consequences.

Watch for areas receiving locally greater new snow amounts along with strong winds. In these areas sensitive human triggered slab avalanches should become increasingly likely.  Watch also for some east facing ridges or slopes that have have had surface snow scoured to the late Jan crust.  New storm snow may bond poorly to any exposed hard crust layers.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The Mt Hood area received over 2 feet of new snow late last week and over the weekend which is significantly greater than what fell in the Washington Cascades.  There were also periods of varied strong winds which built some large and sensitive wind slab conditions especially near and above tree line. These wind slabs have built over cold low density snow or weak faceted snow due to the cold weather.  Late last week and over the weekend the Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reported
column2:
>widespread sensitive wind slabs near and above treeline but mainly on lee north to southeast aspects.  Wind slabs generally ranged from 1-2 ft Friday and Saturday with many 3-4 ft slab releases reported Sunday.  

, ' ',

Vigorous frontal systems will be moving across the Northwest pretty much every day this week. The first front is moving across the area Monday causing increasing west southwest winds, moderate to heavy snow, and a warming trend. This flow will displace the cold air mass that has been over the area. The warming trend will generally build upside down heavier snow over initial lower density snow and low density snow from last week. A few inches at lower elevations to a foot or more of snow at higher elevations should be seen by Tuesday morning.

, ' ',

column1: West south west winds and light snow showers should temporarily decrease on Tuesday at lower snow levels.

The main concerns should be new storm slab on a variety of slope aspects and wind slab mainly on lee aspects from Monday and Monday night. Initial lower density snow, weak or low density snow from last week and faceted snow near crusts in the upper snowpack may continue to make these new layers reactive on Tuesday. Slabs may also be more reactive where they slide on the January crust or scoured surfaces.

Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended above tree-line Tuesday. If you travel near tree-line or below tree-line watch for signs of wind transport and loading on lee slopes. Shooting cracks are always a sign of instability. Even a small wind or storm slab in the wrong terrain such as above cliffs or above steep slopes can have unintended consequences.

Limited snow at the lowest elevations will limit the avalanche danger especially on solar aspects. The mid and base pack should still consist of mostly stable crust and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.
The next front should begin to arrive Tuesday afternoon and evening. The avalanche danger should significantly increase Tuesday night.

, ' ',

A cold front moved across the Northwest on Monday afternoon causing west to southwest winds, moderate to heavy snow, and a warming trend. Snowfall ending Tuesday morning was just in the 6-10 inch range at Mt Hood. This is further building upside down heavier snow over initial lower density snow from last week. The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reports fairly extensive 1 foot explosive and ski triggered storm slab avalanches on lee northeast slopes on Tuesday and hollow underlying lower density layers.

, ' ',

column1: Another stronger front will cross the Northwest Tuesday night to Wednesday morning. This should cause stormy weather with strong west to southwest winds, heavy rain or snow and warming temperatures.

New wind slab will be likely in the higher elevations zone on lee slopes and storm slab will be likely on a wider variety of aspects. The warming temperatures will further build upside down heavier snow over initial lower density snow and weak surface snow from last week. Wind and storm slab may continue to release cold low density snow or weak faceted snow due to the cold weather.
Rain at lower elevations will also load and weaken surface snow layers in this area and wet loose snow avalanches should be possible in the near and below treeline zones.

Natural and triggered avalanches should be likely Tuesday night and Wednesday. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended Wednesday. The avalanche danger may decrease by later Wednesday. But another less defined front may maintain these conditions much of Wednesday so there is uncertainty in the forecast later Wednesday.

Limited snow at the lowest elevations will limit the avalanche danger there. The mid and base pack should still consist of mostly stable crust and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The moisture tap turned back on this week across the Pacific Northwest and we are in the midst of what will likely be at least a week long storm cycle more typical of a PNW winter with quick moving frontal systems arriving roughly every day.  What is not as typical is the
column2: >variety of weak layers buried underneath the newest storm snow. Sustained cold tempeartures last week lead to new
column3: >surface hoar formation, near surface faceting and preserved the generally light amounts of low density snow that fell during last week.  The cold weather also helped to break down crusts in the upper snowpack. Moderate east winds late last week helped form touchy wind slabs.
column4:
> 

, ' ',

Generally 2 - 4 inches of water weight has been added to the snowpack on the west slopes, with 1 to 2.5 ft of new, higher density snow. The higher amounts were seen at Mt. Baker and upper Alpental and Stevens NWAC stations.  Natural avalanches Monday night and again Tuesday night were reported throughout the west slopes with the exception of near Crystal Mtn.  In the near and above treeline zones, colder temperatures and strong westerly winds transported new snowfall and built new wind slab on lees slopes.  A period of easterly flow at Stevens and Snoqualmie Passes helped crossload slopes before a switch to westerly Wednesday morning. 

, ' ',

Near Mt. Baker, Mt. Baker ski patrol reported a natural cycle down below 5000' with the warming and slides up to 2'.  Some slides reached SR 542 Tuesday night. Alpental ski patrol reported a healthy avalanche cycle Tuesday night as well throughout their uncontrolled terrain with most slides initiated within the new storm snow but reaching down to a localized freezing rain crust was formed Sunday, 2/9.  Perhaps the trickiest snowpack continues to be in and near the Stevens Pass area.  DOT professionals reported slides 1-2.5 ft with control work Tuesday morning failing on faceted crystals just above the late Jan crust.  A similar weak layer was involved in a skier triggered avalanche on Big Chief Mtn just outside the ski area boundary Tuesday afternoon around 5000 ft on a NW aspect and resulted in an injury.  NWAC observer Jeff Ward has a
column5:
feature=youtu.be"">great video from Tuesday demonstrating the touchy new storm slab failing on near surface facets and triggering a remote slide near Stevens Pass near treeline and of high quality shears for an increasingly deeply buried layer of surface hoar at lower elevations on a north aspect.   

, ' ',

Note the avalanche danger is locally lower in the Crystal Mountain and south region and over in the Olympics where there has been less new snow and due to reports of better bonding between old and new snow surfaces in the Crystal Mountain area. 

, ' ',
column8:
/>

, ' ',

NWAC observer Jeff Hambelton sent this photo of a storm slab triggered on a test slope at Mt Baker from 10 Feb.

, ' ',

Limited snow at the lowest elevations will limit the avalanche danger there. The mid and base pack should still consist of mostly stable crust and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.

, ' ',

column1: A slightly weaker front should cross the area Wednesday night through Thursday morning with an uptick of west to southwest winds during this time period as well.
Warmer temperatures and a relative break in new loading Wednesday afternoon helped new storm snow instabilities settle, but new loading Wednesday night will reintroduce new storm and wind slab.
Rain at lower elevations will also load and weaken surface snow layers and may cause wet loose avalanches in the lower below treeline zone, likely below 3500 ft.
Natural avalanches will be less likely on Thursday, but large avalanches in specific areas sensitive to skier/rider triggering remains likely.

With the passing of each storm system, the possibility of deeper and more dangerous slabs grows for slopes that have not yet avalanched, potentially releasing to or entraining snow down to near the late Jan crust.  Exercise caution tomorrow and through the rest of the storm cycle by choosing more conservative terrain.
Note the avalanche danger is locally lower in the Crystal Mountain and south region and over in the Olympics.

Hood Meadows respectively during the same time period with a dense 12"" of snow falling over the last 2 days.  West winds gusted over 100 mph at the Cascade Express weather station early Wednesday morning transporting the new dense snow to lee slopes.

Periods of strong winds over the past week built some large and sensitive wind slab conditions especially near and above tree line. column1: Another strong front should spread increasing moderate to heavy precipitation accompanied by very strong crest level winds over the area from the south early Friday.  This weather should rapidly reload avalanche paths that may have already release one or multiple times over the past few days.  On such slopes the new storm snow my fall on exposed hard smooth crust layers causing a poor bond and leading to an elevated danger.  Elsewhere, on slopes that have yet to release, such as lower angled terrain and less wind loaded terrain, the addition of increasing rapid load may tip the balance and cause these slopes to release, either naturally or by human trigger.  Some of these slides may be large to very large with destructive potential.
The bottom line is this is no time to let your guard down.  Similar snowpack structures around the west have lead to numerous recent fatal avalanche accidents including in NE Oregon on Tuesday.
Rain at lower elevations at times may lead to wet snow avalanche conditions for some areas below tree line.
Exercise caution Friday and through the weekend by choosing more conservative terrain and avoid travel in avalanche terrain near and above treeline.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

The Mt Hood NWAC stations have reported over 3-4 feet of snow in the last week with rising snow levels at times late this week creating new crust layers as well as producing widespread natural avalanches, especially Wednesday. Significant water weight as been added with roughly 8-10 inches of water equivalent received  reported at Mt Hood Meadows and Timberline respectively during the same time period.  West winds gusted over 100 mph at the Cascade Express weather station early Wednesday morning transporting the new dense snow to lee slopes.  

, ' ',

Periods of strong winds over the past week built some large and sensitive wind slab conditions especially near and above tree line. These wind slabs have built over cold low density snow or weak faceted snow due to the cold weather.  Late last week and over the weekend the Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reported
column2:
>widespread sensitive wind slabs near and above treeline but mainly on lee north to southeast aspects.  Wind slabs generally ranged from 2-4 ft over this time period.

column1: Yet another strong front should spread increasing moderate to heavy precipitation accompanied by very strong crest level winds over the Mt Hood area Saturday morning, then increasing through the afternoon with heavy loading and very strong winds.  This weather should once again reload avalanche paths that may have already release one or multiple times during the recent storm cycle .  On such slopes the new storm snow my fall on exposed hard smooth crust layers causing a poor bond and leading to an elevated danger.  Elsewhere, on slopes that have yet to release, such as lower angled terrain and less wind loaded terrain, the addition of increasing rapid load may tip the balance and cause these slopes to release, either naturally or by human trigger.  Some of these slides may be large to very large with destructive potential.
New storm snow may load newly formed crusts as well at mainly lower and mid elevations formed over the past few days.
Rain at lower elevations at times may maintain the chances of wet snow avalanche conditions for some areas below tree line.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Recent Regional Weather and Snowpack

, ' ',

An extended dry mild period was seen the latter half of January. The was followed by very cold weather and periods of low density snowfall in early February. Now for the past 5 days the Northwest is getting pummeled by daily frontal systems producing periods of strong winds, periods of warmer higher density snowfall and rain during periods of generally warmer temperatures.

, ' ',

Water equivalents/snow for the past 5 days mostly range as follows: Olympics and Cascades near and west of the crest 3-7 inches WE/2-4 feet of snow, east of the crest 1-4 inches WE/1-2 feet of snow, and at Mt Hood 10-12 inches WE/2-3 feet of snow! Note this is generally heavy wet snow for all areas especially at Mt Hood!

, ' ',

Regionally this weather is generally building heavy denser snow layers over colder lower density and faceted snow from early February over potential hoar frost, faceted snow and crusts from late January. So it is no surprise there has generally been a lot of regional avalanche activity especially in the Washington Cascades and at Mt Hood the past couple days. Several widespread natural avalanche cycles have run their course over the past several days with the largest cycle occurring late Tuesday to early Wednesday.

, ' ',
column2:
>Similar weather and snowpack structures around the west have lead to numerous recent fatal avalanche accidents including in northeast Oregon on Tuesday.

, ' ',

Hurricane Ridge

, ' ',

Our NWAC observer Tyler Reid at Hurricane Ridge on Friday reported a ski triggered D2 avalanche on a northeast slope at 5200 feet. He is also reported 20 cm of F storm snow over a rain crust from Wednesday over another 20 cm of F snow. The crust layer at 20 cm will probably be the interface to watch during the upcoming storm on Sunday.

, ' ',
column4:
/>

, ' ',

Photo by NWAC observer Tyler Reid showing F over crust over F snow on 14 February.

, ' ',

Snow pit tests by Tyler on Saturday gave moderate to hard, sudden planar results and unlikely propagation.

, ' ',

Limited snow at the lowest elevations will limit the avalanche danger there. The mid and base pack should still consist of mostly stable crusts and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

column1: The next very strong cold front will begin to reach the Olympics Sunday midday. This will begin to cause stormy weather with strong winds and heavy snowfall. This system should have cooler temperatures and lower snow levels than the past few systems. Rapid loading should begin to cause new storm slab to begin to build on most sheltered aspects in all the elevations zones Sunday afternoon. Wind transport should cause new wind slab to begin to build on lee slopes mainly near and above treeline. This will begin to add further loads to the rain crust from Wednesday or deep layers. Natural or triggered large avalanches should become possible Sunday midday.

The storm should peak in the Olympics Sunday afternoon and evening. Rapid loading and wind transport will cause storm and wind slab to further build and become deep Sunday afternoon and evening. An avalanche cycle is likely in the near and above treeline zones. Natural or triggered large avalanches are likely near and above treeline Sunday afternoon and evening.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Recent Northwest Weather

, ' ',

An extended dry mild period was seen the latter half of January. The was followed by very cold weather which produced low density snowfall and near surface faceted snow in early February. Now for the past 6 days the Northwest is getting pummeled by daily frontal systems producing periods of strong winds, periods of warmer higher density snowfall and rain during periods of generally warmer temperatures.

, ' ',

Water equivalents at Mt Hood the past 6 days are in the 10-14 inch range with snowfall in the 3-4 foot range. Note this means generally rain and heavy wet snow.

, ' ',

Mt Hood Area

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadow ski patrol reported widespread storm and wind slab up to about 12 inches on Friday and Saturday morning before snow turned to rain later Saturday.

, ' ',

Shallow unconsolidated new snow well bonded to the new rain crust was reported Sunday with little or no avalanche control results.

, ' ',
column2: >While most of the avalanches have been within new snow, The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol was able to awaken a deep persistent weak layer above an old rain or freezing rain crust from mid December several feet deep last Tuesday.  Faceting had occurred in and around the old crust and the crust itself weakening which likely occurred during the dry and cold spells. See photos of the crown below.
column5:

, ' ',

NWAC observer Tom Curtis in the Timberline area above treeline on Thursday found storm and wind slab that was most reactive to ski triggering on steeper roll overs on lee aspects. This short
column6:
>video indicates the kind of stormy conditions that have been seen most of the week on Mt Hood.

, ' ',

The next very strong cold front will cross the Cascades Sunday night and be over the Mt Hood area Monday morning. This will produce stormy weather with very strong winds, slight warming and then cooling, and heavy snowfall. An avalanche cycle is likely Sunday night and Monday morning at Mt Hood.

, ' ',

column1: Strong winds and heavy snow will last into Monday morning at Mt Hood as the front lingers over the area. New potentially deep storm slab will be likely on all sheltered aspects. New potentially deep wind slab will be likely on lee slopes. Natural or triggered avalanches should be likely near or above treeline on Monday. Avalanches initially in storm layers may step down to deeper layers. Travel in avalanche terrain at Mt Hood is not recommended through Monday morning.

Winds and showers should gradually decrease at Mt Hood by Monday afternoon cooler temperatures. The avalanche danger should begin to decrease at Mt Hood Monday afternoon. But dangerous avalanche conditions are still expected Monday afternoon when careful snowpack evaluation cautious route-finding will still be essential.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Recent Northwest Weather

, ' ',

An extended mild and mostly dry period occurred over the latter half of January which allowed a variety of crusts to form. Very cold weather followed in early February which produced low density snowfall, periods of moderate east winds, and strong temperature gradients in the upper snowpack that allowed near surface faceting and broke down previously strong crusts buried in late January. During the last week and the half Mt. Hood has been pummeled almost daily by frontal systems producing periods of strong winds and intense snowfall accumulation.  Snow levels started out quite low during this cycle but over the last week have fluctuated and settled at more moderate levels.  

, ' ',

Water equivalents in the Mt. Hood area over the last week and a half at NWAC stations are 12-17 inches with snowfall around 5 ft in the 5000-6000 foot range. Expect wind loaded slopes above treeline to hold much more new snow from the past week than the generally sheltered weather stations. About 12"" of new snow has fallen in last 36 hours ending 4 pm Monday. 

, ' ',

Mt Hood Area Observations

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadow ski patrol reported widespread storm and wind slab up to about 12 inches on Friday and Saturday morning before snow turned to rain later Saturday.

, ' ',

Shallow unconsolidated new snow well bonded to the new rain crust was reported Sunday with little or no avalanche control results.

, ' ',

Intense loading rates Monday morning with moderate westerly winds seen at NWAC stations and stronger winds likely above treeline loaded all aspects near and below treeline and likely mostly lee aspects near and above treeline. No new reports of how sensitive the new snow were available Monday evening. 

, ' ',

Another fast moving and powerful storm system will impact the Pacific Northwest on Tuesday.  Snowfall will increase first in the Olympics Tuesday morning and spread into Mt. Hood by late morning.  A more southerly flow out ahead of frontal boundary should bring rapid loading rates first to more northerly aspects and then during and following the frontal passage to more traditional easterly aspects as winds veer to more westerly by Tuesday afternoon. A warm-up preceding the frontal passage should cause rain at lower elevations in the below treeline zone and form denser wind and storm slab elsewhere.

New storm slab will form on all sheltered aspects above 4500 feet. New potentially deep wind slab will develop on lee N thru SE slopes. Natural or triggered avalanches will be likely at all elevations. Direct action avalanches that release initially in storm layers seem likely to step down to deeper layers. Wet loose avalanches should become more likely in the afternoon below 4500 feet and may entrain large amounts of the most recent storm snow.
Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended on Tuesday.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Recent Northwest Weather

, ' ',

An extended mild and mostly dry period occurred over the latter half of January which allowed a variety of crusts to form. Very cold weather followed in early February which produced low density snowfall, periods of moderate east winds, and strong temperature gradients in the upper snowpack that allowed near surface faceting and broke down previously strong crusts buried in late January. During the last week the Pacific Northwest has been pummeled almost daily by frontal systems producing periods of strong winds and intense snowfall accumulation at fluctuating and generally moderate snow levels.

, ' ',

Water equivalents in the Cascades near and east of the crest over the last week are 3.5-7 inches with snowfall in the 2-5 ft range at weather stations and Snotels. Expect wind loaded slopes to hold much more new snow from the past week than the generally sheltered weather stations. About 10"" of new snow has fallen near Washington Pass with a very wind affected few inches at Mission Ridge in last 12 hours ending 5 pm Tuesday.  

, ' ',

Washington Cascades east of the crest

, ' ',

The snowpack east of the crest continues to be the trickiest in our forecast area. This is mainly due to colder lower density snow or old near surface faceted snow from early February, buried surface hoar from late January, or potential deep faceted or depth hoar from earlier this winter.

, ' ',

On Friday NWAC observer Jeff Ward at Harts Pass reported a lot of
column4:
>whumphing and extended column testing indicating strong propagation at these layers near Harts Pass at an average depth of 80 cm.  More recently, the reactive faceted layer above or just below the crust has been reported generally over a meter deep in the Hart's Pass and Washington Pass area. This layer is still failing in deep column tests and showing a propensity to propagate. While unlikely that a skier's weight would trigger avalanches this deep, cornices have grown very large over the last week and could be the natural trigger needed to release deeper slides. Since this layer continues to be found, particularly in the northeast Cascades...the persistent slab concern has been changed to deep persistent slab. The forecast discussion remains the same for the east slopes.  Poor weather has limited observations...but NCMG and NCH guides have not seen widespread natural avalanche activity during this storm cycle on the paths possible to view.  

, '\n\n',
column5: >The Mission Ridge ski patrol Friday reported easily triggered widespread slab avalanches some triggered remotely that were stepping from the mid-pack to depth hoar
column6: >at the ground where the overall snowpack depth was limited to about 80-100 cm. On
column7:
> Saturday a skier triggered a 12 inch slab that caught 3 skiers on a NE slope around 6300 ft within the Mission Ridge ski area, luckily without serious injury. Hard wind slab blocks were in the 5 feet of debris. See photo below. 

, '\n\n',
column8:
>Stevens Pass DOT reported that a natural avalanche reached US 2 early Monday morning in Tumwater Canyon. 

, ' ',

New loading this past week has reactivated PWLs found east of the crest.

, ' ',
column10:

, ' ',

Photo of Mission Ridge skier triggered slab avalanche Saturday afternoon by Brad Whiting of Mission Ridge ski patrol.

, ' ',

Recent snowfall at lower elevations has allowed avalanche paths to fill somewhat and allow potential avalanche to run further and lower than earlier in what was previously a well below normal snowfall season. 

, ' ',

column1: Competing factors on Wednesday will keep dangerous avalanche conditions in play despite a relative break in the storm cycle and a favorable temperature trend.  A cooling trend overnight Tuesday and continuing on Wednesday should build lower density snow on top of Tuesday's soft storm slab and allow new storm instabilities to slowly settle. An exception may be found locally in persistent heavy showers slopping east of the crest near a
column2: > convergence zone expected to form near Stevens Pass tonight and eventually shift south toward Snoqualmie Pass mid-day where new loading may stress the most recent storm layer instabilities
column3: >. In addition moderate westerly winds will continue to load lee easterly aspects throughout the day Wednesday. South to southeast winds ahead of Tuesday's frontal system near the passes may have cross loaded slopes before winds switched to westerly so NW aspects have been added to the wind slab concern.

column1: Expect snow conditions to still be touchy on Wednesday and human triggered avalanches will be likely mainly on lee NW thru SE aspects at all elevations. Triggered avalanches are likely to start and stay in the new snow from yesterday...but the potential exists for very large avalanches in specific areas that release down to stiffer wind slab layers or buried persistent weak layers described in the forecast discussion. Recently formed and sensitive cornices along ridgelines are an example of a natural trigger that could be large enough to trigger a much deeper and very destructive slide.  Shallow snowpack areas increase the likelihood of a skier's weight collapsing a buried persistent weak layer and having the fracture propagate across the slope.
Stick with conservative terrain choices for another day and let all the recent snow and associated water weight received over the last week a chance to settle.

Mt Hood Area Observations

, ' ',

The Mt Hood Meadow ski patrol reported widespread storm and wind slab up to about 12 inches on Friday and Saturday morning before snow turned to rain later Saturday.
column2:
>Shallow unconsolidated new snow well bonded to the new rain crust was reported Sunday with little or no avalanche control results.

, ' ',

Intense loading rates Monday morning with moderate westerly winds seen at NWAC stations and stronger winds above treeline loaded all aspects near and below treeline and likely mostly lee aspects near and above treeline. Mount Hood Meadows pro patrol very sensitive storm slab Monday near treeline averaging 8-12"".  By Tuesday early afternoon, Meadows patrol reported less sensitive storm slab near treeline but slabs of 12-18"" on wind loaded NE aspects above treeline and around 7000 feet with explosives.  Heavy loading occurred later Tuesday afternoon and early evening potentially introducing new storm snow instabilities.  Limited visibility and strong winds especially above treeline limited observations Monday and Tuesday. 

, ' ',

Additional storm and wind slab releases from 1-2 feet were triggered mainly with explosives Wednesday at Mt Hood Meadows on mainly N-NE aspects from 4800-6600' 

, ' ',

column1: Additional loading in showers Wednesday will transition into increased frontal snowfall and strengthening winds Wednesday night and Thursday morning while remaining cool.  This should add additional loading from storm layers to new wind slab over existing deep storm slabs and older wind slab layers.  Strong westerly winds through early Thursday will build large wind slab layers on a variety of lee aspects ranging from NW-SE with many slopes or features being cross loaded by wind transport.

Expect snow conditions to be touchy on Thursday and very sensitive to human triggers.  The most likely slopes to trigger avalanches should be mainly on lee NW thru SE aspects. Triggered avalanches are likely to start and stay in the new snow as of Thursday morning, however the potential exists for some very large avalanches in specific areas that release down to older storm and stiffer wind slab layers or the rain crust from last week. Recently formed and sensitive cornices along ridgelines are an example of a natural trigger that could be large enough to trigger a much deeper and very destructive slide.
Stick with very conservative terrain choices and let all the recent snow and associated water weight received over the last 13 days have time to settle.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Recent Northwest Weather

, ' ',

An extended mild and dry period occurred the latter half of January generally causing a crust to form in all areas. Very cold weather followed in early February in the Olympics which produced low density snowfall and strong temperature gradients in the upper snowpack that generally caused surface hoar frost and faceting near the crust.

, ' ',

During the past 10 days the Pacific Northwest has been pummeled almost daily by frontal systems producing periods of strong winds and heavy snowfall. The latest storm Wednesday night and Thursday morning has brought another round of heavy snow. The water equivalent at Hurricane over the past 10 days is about 7 inches with snowfall about 5 feet at the NWAC weather station.

, ' ',

Observations for Washington Cascades near and west of the crest

, ' ',

Several avalanche cycles have been seen the past 10 days. West of the crest the January crust has become buried pretty deeply and although some recent avalanches have been big it seems there isn't any confirmed activity down to that layer lately. Forecast attention near and west of the crest will be focused on recent storm layers.

, ' ',

A cold front Tuesday evening caused heavy loading rates at gradually warming temperatures. This caused a widespread natural avalanche cycle that was observed in many areas by Wednesday morning with numerous wind and storm slab avalanches noted from the Mt Baker, Snoqualmie Pass and Crystal Mountain and Crystal Mountain ski areas. Some of the avalanches were up to 3-5 feet deep!

, ' ',

Another front moved past on Wednesday night and Thursday morning causing denser snow at warmer temperatures. Easy ski triggering of storm slabs on Thursday up to about 1-1.5 feet mainly on lee slopes was reported by ski areas including Mt Baker and Alpental.

, ' ',
column2:
>The mid and base pack at Hurricane should still consist of mostly stable crusts and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.

, '\n\n',

column1: The amazing storm cycle of the past 10 days is winding down. Winds should decrease and light snow showers should end on Friday with cool temperatures. But deep avalanche layers will not go away right away.
This weather will start to bring some stabilizing to recent snow layers. The main concerns at Hurricane will be recently formed wind and storm slab layers.

Deep wind slab will be mostly likely on lee slopes at higher elevations. Watch for signs of firmer wind transported snow. Deep storm slab will be left in the forecast for Friday in case it needs another day to stabilize. Deep storm slab should still be possible on Friday on sheltered aspects from above to below treeline.

, ' ',

, ' ',

Several natural avalanche crowns were noted in White River Canyon.

, ' ',

Wind were strong Thursday night at Mt Hood and continue pretty strong on Friday as seen at the NWAC Mt Hood Meadows weather station. The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reports lots of wind effects from that period.

column1: Northwest flow will help carry a weak low pressure system northwest to southeast across the Olympics and Washington Cascades on Saturday. At Mt Hood this should cause west northwest winds but with little if any snow and cool temperatures. This should cause little change in snow and avalanche conditions.
Layers from the past 11 days should partly stabilize. Possible older deeper wind slab may linger on previous lee slopes mainly at higher elevations. Watch for signs of firmer wind transported snow.
Previous older deeper storm slab on sheltered slopes should be mostly stabilized and unlikely by Saturday.

The sun is starting to get stronger as we head toward March. Watch for sun effects such as roller balls and pinwheels on solar slopes that could trigger a loose wet avalanche or a wind or storm slab layer on a steep slope.

Saturday was the first relative break in a seemingly endless storm cycle over the last two weeks. Several avalanche cycles have been seen over the past 2 weeks. Near Mt. Hood the January crust has become deeply buried and there is not any recent natural or human triggered activity down to that layer.  Forecast attention will be focused on recent storm and wind layers.

Several natural avalanche crowns were noted in White River Canyon on Thursday as well as sensitive storm slabs after a frontal system moved through Wednesday night and Thursday morning causing denser snow at warmer temperatures to overlie weaker colder snow.

Strong winds buffeted Mt Hood Thursday night and Friday before the weather subsided over the weekend. Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reported wind effects dominating the above treeline zone this weekend. NW winds created a thick wind crust down near treeline and created widespread and thick sastrugi on exposed windward ridges and slopes.

, ' ',

As Meadows professional ski patrol ventured further up their terrain Saturday, they reported little in the way of results with ski cutting or explosives through mid-day.  

, ' ',
column2:
>The mid and base pack at Mt Hood should still consist of mostly stable crusts and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.

column1: A frontal system passing through Sunday night should produce generally light amounts of new precipitation at moderate snow levels and moderate westerly winds on the upper mountain. Another warm front should lift through the area in the afternoon but again no significant accumulations are expected.

However snow levels should continue to creep up overnight and through Monday...extending the reach for wet loose avalanches into the near treeline zone on all aspects with light rain saturating the most recent storm snow potentially up to 6500 feet Monday. Watch for heavier surface snow that begins to naturally pinwheel on steeper slopes.  Wet-loose avalanches may start small but entrain large amounts of snow.  Avoid terrain traps and steep slopes and watch for signs of natural wet loose activity.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Deep recent storm snow after the weekend has been drastically changed in the Snoqualmie Pass area as of Tuesday morning. Early Monday morning a period of freezing rain occurred in the Snoqualmie Pass area depositing a thin crust.  An additional 6 to 8 inches of new snow fell over that layer before a more widespread freezing rain event occurred overnight Monday.  This has left a clear supportable ice layer capping deeper low density snow that fell earlier.  

, ' ',

While the current conditions do not support an avalanche danger, they do support a falling and sliding hazard as the surface in most areas is a smooth hard ice layer.

, ' ',

There remains to be a concern for deep slab releases in this area, given the many recent large slides over the past week.  However with the current ice structure it will likely take a significant trigger, such as a very large cornice collapse to possibly initiate a slide to that deep layer.  Reports of a very large natural hard slab avalanche off steep north facing terrain of Chair Peak near Alpental partially caught 3 skiers Saturday. Luckily no on was injured in this potentially deadly avalanche with a 10' crown.  It is believed this slide was initiated by a smaller slide or possible cornice failure then stepped down to the deep layer. This avalanche paired with the frequent and large results from ski patrol should steer the discussion to terrain management of low probability and high consequence slides that release down to old storm layers or the late Jan crust.

, ' ',
Expect snow conditions in the Snoqualmie Pass area to remain similar to Tuesday as cool east winds should maintain near or sub-freezing temperatures helping to maintain that ice crust on most slopes.

Human triggered large or very large avalanches have become unlikely but are still high consequence if able to step down to poorly bonded previous storm layers or buried persistent weak layers. Cornices have grown large and may be sensitive. A cornice failure could provide a large enough natural trigger to trigger a large and destructive avalanche.  Avoid areas in avalanche terrain where you believe the snowpack to be shallower and potentially easier to trigger a deep PWL.

column1: Mild temperatures, mostly cloudy skies and light to moderate showers Wednesday night through Thursday morning will likely prevent a healthy refreeze on wet surface snow.  Snow levels will be slightly cooler Thursday but wet-loose avalanches will still be the primary concern especially during any potential sunny periods in the afternoon.

Watch for wet surface snow conditions and given the deep recent storm snow, expect any wet-loose avalanches that start small to possibly entrain large amounts of snow.  Avoid terrain traps and steep slopes and watch for signs of natural wet loose activity.
Not much is known about any lingering wind slab instabilities above treeline.

column1: Significant cooling is expected Friday night and Saturday with mostly cloudy conditions and light snow showers expected Saturday. This weather should cause the previously wet surface and upper snow layer to re-freeze, forming a hard and supportable crust.  The surface or near surface crust should limit the avalanche potential, especially near and below tree line.  Shallow new snow received Saturday should not appreciably increase the danger, however some strengthening winds may begin to form shallow new storm layers on some lee slopes at higher elevations by late Saturday.

In areas where the forming surface crust has significant surface roughness, this may help new snow bonding.  However the rapidly dropping temperatures expected Friday night ahead of the onset of precipitation Saturday may counter that in many areas where poor bonding may develop.

The strengthening new surface crust expected Saturday should cause generally safe avalanche conditions.  However continue to watch for unstable snow on isolated terrain features, especially above treeline.  Also watch for recently formed large cornices along ridges and give them a wide birth and safety margin.
column3: > of these cornices have grown large over the last 2 weeks and a cornice failure could provide a large enough load to trigger a large avalanche.

Increasing strong winds, gradually rising temperatures with heavier precipitation rates Sunday should all combine to cause a significant increase in the danger Sunday.

column1: Another weather system passing through the Mt. Hood area on Monday should bring a rapid increase in precipitation rates mid-day with predominately W to SW winds loading lee slopes. The rain line should stay near or below 5000 feet Monday.  In this zone, wet loose avalanches will be the primary concern especially on rain soaked steeper slopes.  New wind and storm slab should bond well given the warm temperatures, but intense precipitation rates may produce storm layer instabilities Monday near and above treeline.

column2: >Storm slab will also be listed as a concern near and above treeline on all aspects although expect the most loading on lee aspects. Wetter denser new snow accumulating over lower density snow in the above treeline zone will contribute to this concern.

column1: Dense wind slab is most likely above treeline and likely has grown large on lee N thru SE aspects over the last few days.  Not much is known how newly formed wind slab has bonded during this storm cycle.

Snowpack Analysis:

, ' ',

Recent Weather

, ' ',
column2: >An extended mild and dry period occurred the latter half of January generally forming a crust in all areas.
column3: >Very cold weather followed in early February which produced light low density snowfall and facets just above the late January crust.
column4:
>A two week storm cycle ended on 2/25 producing 7-12 feet of snowfall and many avalanche cycles near and west of the crest.

, '\n\n',
column5: >Warm and mainly dry weather at the end of February led to wet snow avalanches and melt/freeze crusts.
column6:
>Temperatures dropped significantly by Sunday prior to the onset of a new storm cycle. This caused poor bonding of the initial snowfall to the newly formed crust layer in most areas. 

, ' ',

A series of fronts moved across the PNW this week from Sunday through Thursday. Snow levels rose through these events causing rain or wet snow conditions to about 5500 ft in the north, 6000 ft central and 7000 ft or higher in the south. Snow levels moderated a bit on Thursday's storm and 6-12 inches of heavy wet snow fell through Friday morning above 4500-5000 feet. Six day water equivalents are around 6-9 inches through Friday morning and snowfall of about 2-6 feet, with even heavier amounts expected higher in elevation. Friday was a break in the storm cycle with partly sunny skies in the afternoon and moderate freezing levels. Snow surfaces were reported as a mix of heavy wet snow at mid elevations, with lighter snow above 5000 feet. 

, ' ',

Washington Cascades near and west of the crest

, ' ',

The latest storm cycle began on Sunday. Initially lower density snow bonded poorly to the melt-freeze crust from late last week and lead to an avalanche cycle Sunday night and Monday morning. DOT crews at Stevens and Snoqualmie reported widespread natural and triggered 1-2 foot avalanches Sunday night and Monday morning which closed Snoqualmie Pass. 

, ' ',

Snow levels have been rising and temperatures warming Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday with heavy rain or wet snow producing several avalanche cycles. Alpental ski patrol and Snoqualmie and Stevens Pass DOT reported another round of natural avalanches Tuesday night and Wednesday morning with mostly loose wet snow avalanches. However some larger natural releases were noted above cliff bands where unsupported slabs released above rock faces slopes as well as some glide cracks. Loose wet snow avalanches releasing during control work entrained quite a bit of the underlying storm snow. Crystal mountain reported similar reports Thu AM with a wet snow avalanche off of Rockface gouging down to deeper layers and running a fair distance. Only a few reports of natural small loose wet slides were available by Friday afternoon near and below treeline from observer Jeff Hambelton in the Mt. Baker area and Alpental ski patrol.  Check out Jeff's latest video contribution from the Mt. Baker area

3-5-14, Point release (wet loose) that gouged to the ground, Spiral Butte nr White Pass, Photo John Stimberis WSDOT

column10: >The late January crust and faceted layers for early February are
column11: >now very deeply buried and have been getting tested by the recent heavy precipitation. In the Snoqualmie and Stevens Pass area this interface has been reported 2-3 m (6-10 ft) deep around 4000 feet, and to about 3 m in the Mt. Baker area around 5700 ft. Very large avalanches down to this layer, either natural or triggered with large explosives have not been reported in last week and a half including during the last storm cycle. We are close to dropping the deep persistent
column12: > slab concern due to how deep this layer is and how un-reactive during the latest round of natural avalanche cycles. However, we will wait until the recent warm and wet period comes to an end. Downhill creep in the upper snowpack or large wet snow avalanches present

column1: A warm and moist frontal system will impact the Pacific Northwest over the weekend. Light rain and snow should begin in the north Cascades Saturday morning and become heavy in the afternoon along with increasing southwest winds. Light rain and snow should develop by the late morning for the central and south Washington Cascades and not become heavy until the late afternoon and evening.

column2: >Steep slopes that recently received heavy snowfall should be primed for wet loose avalanches, especially when loaded with rain Saturday. Natural pinwheeling of surface snow is usually a precursor to this type of avalanche. Expect wet loose avalanches to potentially entrain moist and unconsolidated snow at near and below treeline and could make for a large and destructive wet snow avalanche in specific areas. Lower density storm snow at higher elevations received during the week will be in play for loose wet avalanches by Saturday afternoon. If you are sinking in more than ankle deep, expect wet loose avalanches to be possible on steeper slopes. With the continuing warm temperatures, cornices are still expected to be sensitive so give them a wide berth when traveling along ridgelines.

column1: Dense storm and wind slab should begin to develop mainly in the above treeline zone (depending on the snow level) Saturday. Despite a favorable temperature trend, heavy loading rates will likely lead to storm snow instabilities. Strong SW winds will build dense and large wind slab on lee slopes Saturday afternoon and night.
The north Cascades and Olympics have a higher danger related to more quickly escalating avalanche danger Saturday. T
column2: >he avalanche forecast is for the daylight hours (through 6 pm) but deteriorating avalanche conditions are expected Saturday night with natural avalanches becoming likely as heavy rain reaches into the above treeline zone and loads recently formed storm slabs at higher elevations.

column5:
>The current storm cycle began last weekend with initially cool temperatures and poor bonds to the end of February crust in many areas. This storm cycle is turning out to be almost as wet as the last one! Water equivalents and snowfall for the current storm cycle will be about 8.5-10.5 inches but only about 2-3 feet of snowfall ending Sunday morning at Mt Hood. This cycle has been producing many avalanches all week in the Cascades.

, ' ',

>The mid and base pack at Mt Hood should still consist of mostly stable crusts and melt form layers from periods of warm weather earlier this winter.

, '\n\n ',

column1: Another potential major wet loose avalanche cycle is likely during frontal passage and heavy rain or snow at warmer temperatures Saturday afternoon and night. Cornice failures are also likely during that period.

But rain or snow showers decrease rapidly on Sunday morning at slightly cooler temperatures. Significant new snow is not expected or should be very limited. A decreasing avalanche danger is expected on Sunday.
The main concern will be lingering wet loose snow avalanches. This is most likely on steep slopes that do not release on Saturday night. Watch for
column2: > further pinwheeling of surface snow and wet snow still deeper than a few inches which often precede this type of avalanche. Loose wet avalanches may still entrain deeper wet snow and be large and destructive.

, '\n\n',
column3:

, '\n\n',
column4:
>The second storm cycle is coming to an end on Sunday morning. This storm cycle turned out to be basically as wet as the last one! Water equivalents and snowfall for the past week are about 9-12 inches and 2-3 feet respectively for NWAC stations at Mt Hood. So this has been another period of rain and wet heavy snowfall. This produced many avalanches the past week again especially in the Washington Cascades last week.

, ' ',

The last front of the second cycle moved across the area on Sunday morning and a few more avalanches were seen in the Washington Cascades. The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol on Sunday reports saturated surface snow layers with conditions not warranting skiing above about 6600 feet.

column1: A short wave should move mainly across south Oregon and north California on Sunday night and Monday morning. This should cause moderate showers as far north as Mt Hood.

The equinox is not too far off and the sun is gaining power. The sun and potential new snow should make further triggered wet loose avalanches possible on Monday mainly below treeline. Watch for pinwheels and new surface wet snow deeper than a few inches.
The new snow should also make shallow new storm slab likely on sheltered slopes mainly near or above treeline. At least a few inches of new snow will be necessary for this to be a concern.
Older areas of wind slab might still be seen at the highest elevations. Watch for signs of firmer wind transported snow in the highest areas above treeline.

>Field reports from the Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol Tuesday and Wednesday mainly indicated deep wet snow with the potential for deeper wet snow avalanches. The upper part of the ski area was closed Wednesday due to wet snow concerns. But explosive avalanche control did not produce avalanches.

, ' ',

By Thursday there has been a couple days of daytime warming and night time cooling in all areas. The upper snowpack has temporarily stabilized and no significant avalanches have been reported the past couple days. The Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol reports a thick surface crusts is only softening on Thursday afternoon.

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

column1: A moderate cold front will approach from the west Thursday night and cross the Northwest on Friday morning. This will be accompanied by increasing winds, moderate rain or snow and slightly lowering snow levels. Showers following the front should decrease Friday afternoon.

New wind slab is likely on lee slopes. You should be most likely to trigger a wind slab on north to southeast aspects near and above treeline. Watch for signs of firmer wind transported snow or cracking snow.
New storm slab is also likely on sheltered slopes again mainly near and above treeline. This is most likely in any areas that receive an inch of snow or more an hour for at least a few hours.

It is now March and the sun is getting stronger. Watch for sun effects on new snow mainly on solar aspects but possibly aspects as well. Wet loose avalanches are becoming more likely if you see pinwheels or initial small natural wet loose releases.

In sheltered areas where the winds are not strong and the snowfall not heavy the increase in avalanche danger should be more limited. In such areas the cooling trend may also help create right side up layering with lower density snow near the surface.

Recent Weather Summary

, ' ',
column2: >Over the past month two major storm cycles moved across the Pacific Northwest. The most recent week long storm cycle occurred
column3: > in early March and wound down last Sunday. This storm cycle produced similar water equivalents as the February cycle
column4: water equivalents and snowfall for the the second cycle were about 2.5-8 inches and 1-3 feet at most NWAC sites east of the crest.
column5:
> This cycle was warmer and featured mainly wet snow and rain leading to several natural avalanche cycles during the first week of March.  However, the northeast Cascades received mostly snow, albeit wet snow from the strong frontal system last weekend. Average freezing levels have been roughly 2000-3000 feet higher thus far in March versus February! 

, '\n\n',
column6:
>A crust and an old faceted snow layer from late January and early February and basal facets remain concerns east of the crest. These layers vary quite a bit depending on location.

, ' ',

A frontal system passed through Friday morning followed by moderate westerlies that built new wind slab on lee easterly aspects mainly near the Cascade crest by Friday afternoon. 

, ' ',

South and east of Wentachee:  NWAC observer Tom Curtis near Blewett Pass on March 5th and again on March 13th found large faceted crystals near the ground producing sensitive results in snowpit tests on north though east aspects near and above treeline. Here it seems the shallower snowpack provided more opportunity for triggering. Snow has melted out on many solar aspects in the Blewett area up to 6000 feet during the most recent warm stretch. Tom and Mission Ridge snow professionals reported more rounding of the faceted layers at lower elevations. 

, ' ',
column7:
>Northeast Cascades including Washington Pass: NWAC observer Jeff Ward in the Highway 20 corridor reported one small ski triggered wind slab on Monday. But he also reported a large natural wind slab release on a high E slope that stepped down to about 3 meters.

, '\n\n',
column9:
/>

, ' ',

Wind slab release that stepped to about 3 meters in the Highway 20 corridor about Monday 10 March by NWAC observer Jeff Ward.

, ' ',

On Friday Jeff Ward reported new storm and wind slab bonding poorly to a sun crust on solar aspects and to potentially preserved surface hoar on northerly aspects near Washington Pass. The poor bond lead to several observed size 1 and 2 natural wind and storm slab releases by Friday afternoon. 

, ' ',

Due to a deeper snowpack and rounding of the persistent weak layers, the late Jan/early Feb facet crust combo is no longer expected to be a concern in the northeast Cascades.  Observer Jeff Ward and forecaster Dennis D'Amico found the this layer to be non-reactive to PSTs in a pit above 7000 ft on a south aspect near Washington Pass and this layer was not reported as involved during the most recent natural avalanche cycle.  

, ' ',

column1: A warm front should stay draped over the US/Canadian border Saturday, producing moderate precipitation at rapidly increasing snow levels for mainly the northeast Cascades. Warming but only light precipitation is forecast for the central east Cascades and the south east Washington Cascades may see filtered sun.

column2: >Moderate westerly winds on Friday may have built sensitive shallow wind slab on lee easterly aspects in the central east Cascades.

column3: >atch for sun effects on the new snow from Friday mainly on solar aspects especially above 5000 feet. Wet loose avalanches are becoming more likely if you see pinwheels or initial small natural wet loose releases.

column2: >Deep persistent slab is gradually becoming less reactive and less extensive east of the crest. But it is still a concern for east of the crest south and east of Wentachee and it should still be a good plan to avoid large open slopes.

, ' ',

A few inches of heavy wet snow was received around treeline on Friday with a frontal passage in the morning that delivered over an inch of water to the Meadows and Timberline stations. Showers in the afternoon added a few more inches as well as mixed in some graupel, with rain likely below 5000 feet.  Moderately strong westerly winds likely built new wind slab in the alpine. 

, ' ',

As of Saturday morning most of the previously wet snow had begun to refreeze forming a semi-supportable crust, with some wet snow areas remaining.  In general the upper snowpack has temporarily stabilized and no significant avalanches were reported over the past two days.

column1: A frontal system that has been slow to move onshore should gradually approach the Mt Hood area later Sunday.  However much of the day should see sunshine or gradually filtered sunshine through increasing clouds and mild temperatures.  This should maintain surface wet snow conditions through the day so watch for the typical evidence of wet snow concerns such as small wet loose avalanches over snow more than about boot top on steeper sun exposed slopes.  Very light rain is possible late in the day Sunday near Mt. Hood.

column2: >Increasing rain and snow at lowering freezing levels is expected Sunday night.  This should develop new wind slab on lee aspects mainly above treeline. Approach wind loaded slopes with caution and watch for cracking in the snow surface as a sign of instability.

Recent Weather Summary

, ' ',

A front Friday deposited about 1-1.5 inches of water over the Mt Hood areas with much of it as rain below 5500 feet with heavy wet snow and strong winds above 6000 feet.  A very warm and sunny day Saturday caused significant surface snow melt with clearing overnight leaving a hard and shinny crust as of Sunday morning on most slopes. 

, ' ',

Very mild temperatures again Sunday have softened surface snow conditions once again.  The last few days of melt and refreeze are limiting current and near term avalanche concerns to new storm instabilities.  

, ' ',

A stalled moist  frontal boundary has been draped over mainly the North WA Cascades since Saturday afternoon with the recent active weather confined to the north Cascades and Olympics while Mt Hood has remained well south of the activity, but not for long.  

, ' ',

Earlier weather conditions

, ' ',

column3: > Mt Hood area amounting to 2-4 feet of snow.   Mostly warm dry weather this past week was dotted with a brief warm and wet system Friday giving way to sunshine and warm weather again Saturday.
column5: >Field reports from the Mt Hood Meadows ski patrol earlier this week indicated deep wet snow with the potential for deeper wet snow avalanches. The upper part of the ski area was closed Wednesday due to wet snow concerns, but

, ' ',

column1: The strong front across the WA Cascades Sunday should shift south over the Mt Hood area overnight bringing  a period of moderate to heavy snow and strong winds.  This should build new wind slab on lee terrain near and especially above treeline. The bonds of new snow to a refreezing crust should be good given the slow cooling trend.

A cool upper trough should pass the Cascades early Monday with cool but drying northwesterly flow expected through the day Monday.  A few light snow showers early Monday should give way to partly to mostly cloudy conditions with increasing and strong northwest winds lasting through the day.

This weather should allow for the older wet snow to form a more solid underlying crust which may act as a sliding surface.  The strong winds should transport recent snow, mainly above treeline but look for transported snow near tree line as well.  Winds should shift to more northwesterly Monday so watch for wind slab formation on east to south facing slopes.

column2: >Storm slabs should begin to slowly stabilize Monday but should remain a concern and expect triggered slides to remain likely on steeper open terrain where cautious route-finding and conservative decision making will be essential.

column2: >A front Friday deposited about 1-1.5 inches of water over the Mt Hood areas with much of it as rain below 5500 feet with heavy wet snow and strong winds above 6000 feet.  A very warm and sunny day Saturday caused significant surface snow melt with clearing overnight leaving a hard and shinny crust as of Sunday morning on most slopes.  This crust would become an active bed surface on Monday.
column3:
>Very mild temperatures again Sunday have soften surface snow conditions once again but led to few avalanche concerns. 

, ' ',

A front that had been hung up over the Washington Cascades most of the weekend finally sagged south Sunday night with a strong cooling trend, moderate precipitation and strong northwest winds seen near and above treeline.  Locally moderate to heavy snow showers with blustery NW winds continued Monday. The Meadows and Timberline stations reported 18-21 inches through Monday afternoon with good wind transport of new snow reported.  

, ' ',

Mt. Hood Meadows ski patrol had an active day of avalanche control with shallow but sensitive storm slab on all aspects as of late Monday morning, generally 4-6"" but some slabs were up to 1 foot.  Venturing above treeline with poor visibility into Heather Canyon the strong winds had scoured down to the slick crust from Saturday and redeposited snow down near treeline. Locally the wind transported snow bonded poorly to the slick crust and allowed for easy ski triggering with good propagation on slabs up to 2' thick. 

, ' ',

 

, ' ',

column1: Light warm frontal rain and snow should stick over Washington on Tuesday and there may be a few sunbreaks through midday before clouds thicken in the afternoon over Mt. Hood.

A modest warming Tuesday afternoon should lead to minor loose wet concerns on all aspects.  Small point releases on steeper slopes have a fair bit of new and consolidated snow to entrain and would be the most problematic around terrain traps.  Storm slab avalanches should be still be possible given the reports of poor bonding to the old snow surface.

Generally soft wind slab at higher elevations may still be sensitive, and we advise the most caution when traveling at higher and more open avalanche terrain that may be wind loaded and where colder temperatures should preserve lingering instabilities.  Watch for cracking in the snow surface and for signs of obvious wind transport such as scoured lee ridges with wind slab extending well into the near treeline zone.
